reviewText:
My take after 5 hours... I would both recommend and also discourage people to buy/not buy this, but I could only chose one option so please read on to see why!


Performance - Does it run?

After an initial drama with getting it to run at my native resolution - the game crashed every time I switched res and eventually I had to change it in the config file to get it to load - on my machine yes it does, and very very well.. However I'm lucky enough to have just upgraded to the following:

i7 6700k @ Stock 4.0GHz
Asus Maximus VIII Hero Mobo
16GB G.Skill Ripjaws V 3000MHz
MSI GTX 980Ti Gaming 6G

Now I realise this is at the upper end of the hardware scale, and if you're in a position similar to me you can expect to be able to play at a minimum of 100fps (average of ~130) on 1080p with every setting on maximum, so I'm expecting 80-90 on 1440p when I get a new monitor in a couple of weeks (will update with the actual figure).

The game seems to be a bit of a memory hog and while playing it my system uses about 8.2GB with just the game and a few google chrome tabs open, so this could potentially be an issue for people with less.

As others have commented, the initial game loading times are quite slow (using an SSD), however once the map is loaded in, the missions etc load very quickly.


Gameplay / Feel

I've only played 5 hours but this is my 2c so far..

The game looks jaw dropping and if I'm honest is half the reason I bought it, to see what my new system was capable of. I messed around a bit with lowering some of the graphic settings and with a lot of them the quality of the game doesn't decrease too much and you can gain a few fps by doing this, so I wouldn't be worried about how its going to look if you play at medium etc - it will still be incredibly pretty.

After getting over the initial oooooo this is pretty thoughts, the actual game itself is fun in the respect of being able to mindlessly blow things up and fly about like a super-spider-bat-man kind of combo thing (it's bizarre!) It's fun jumping in a tank and blowing up a petrol station, or in a helicopter that has infinite spammable missiles, or planting mines on a bridge, then causing a pile up before blowing the whole thing up etc etc...

Regarding the campaign / story, well to me (admittedly a Just Cause noob) the premise is a bit thin.. a dictator has gone a bit mental and therefore we need to crush him and his minions by taking over towns, then more towns, and a few more, and then a couple more after that.. you get the point. These towns are all just clones of one another and there are only so many fun and creative" ways to shoot

reviewText:
Steam really needs a one thumb up and one thumb down option. I love Just Cause, so I was really excited about this release. Especially when they talked about improving the driving physics and other tweaks to make gameplay better. JC has one of the most fun open world environments, and is a great destructive sandbox. Unfortunately in my small gameplay time so far, there are a lot of cons.

1) You still move like you have one leg. As you turn you spin, in a 360degree fashion, not just simply turn. This makes for awkward movement when you need to face and activate an object.

2)Driving is still a negative. While DRASTICALLY improved over JC2, there is still a lot of work to be done here. Instead of fast paced and moving on ice as in JC2, JC3 is a slowed down drive on sticky tarmac. Turning is slow at first then exagerated to the left or right very quickly.

3)Controller/keyboard controls. I have to use both. I use the controller for general movement and the mouse for aiming/shooting. Neither one performs exceptionally well on their own so I've found a compromise and use both.

4)The map is not very informative. Also, in doing the missions, you have to be close to your objectives if they are in white. (Things you need to do to control settlements.) Yellow indicators appear from any location and are easy to find your destination. Once you are there however, they become white, and are things you need to explode or activate to complete your mission, and can be a pain to find.

5)Enemies seem to pop in out of thin air sometimes. Not from a great distance mind you one time it happened from 10 feet away.

6)The leaderboard function. Both a Pro and a Con here. Con is anytime logging in it takes a bit longer with this feature active, popups can get annoying.

7)It seems AMD users are having problems with some texture popin and textures failing to load. AMD users need to stay away until a patch is introduced for you guys.  I did not experience this with my Nvidia EVGA 980Ti SC ACX+
Square_Jason has been active reguarding this problem http://steamcommunity.com/app/225540/discussions/0/485623406959941125/

Pros
1)Graphics. The game looks very nice.

2)Performance. Im running a single 980Ti in 4k@60 fps with absolutely no frame drops. It's a very solid performer.

3)The leaderboard function. Both a Pro and a Con, it's fun seeing what your friends do in game and trying to beat them.

4)Destruction. Very fun to blow things up still and very many creative ways of doing it, from grappling, grapple tether, guns, bombs, cars, planes, etc.

5)Open world sandbox. This is the bread and butter of Just Cause, and with 1000km2 of open world to explore it delivers again.

SIDENOTE: The airstrikes the enemy calls on you are REALLY ANNOYING...they have amazing accuracy on moving targets. Use this to your advantage! Stand next to a target, let them bomb missiles on their own equipment! Rinse and repeat to take out settlements without firing a single rocket.

SPECS: i7 4930k, 32g ram, EVGA 980Ti SC ACX+ , ASUS 4k monitor @60 fps


These will get updated as I continue playing, and while there are a ton of negatives it is still JC and a very fun game to play.

Despite all of these negatives it's a very fun game. 7/10 so far.

reviewText:
OverviewIâ€™ve played about 45 hours of Just Cause 3. In that time, Iâ€™ve done 54% of the challenges, liberated all provinces, found all collectibles and beaten the game.

It has had its ups and downs, but overall, the game works. Yes, it stutters. Yes, itâ€™s beyond poorly optimized, but itâ€™s still a fun, if overly repetitive, game.

I played this on an i7-4790k with 8GB of RAM and a GTX 980 Ti. After about two hours, the game would get stuttery, and the audio would stutter as well. Simple solution for me (not guaranteed to work) was to alt+tab out of the game, tab back in, and it worked fine for another couple of hours. Only twice did I have to quit out of the game and restart it to clear any stutter issues.

That said, if youâ€™re still interested in the game in its current state (as of this review), continue on. If not, perhaps come back to the game after a patch or two and decide if it is worth it for you to buy then.

ProsJust plain fun to blow things up constantly
Big open world
Lots to do (races, frenzies, wingsuiting, etc.)
Opportunity to create unique situations with physics and the upgrades available to you
Fairly lengthy, will take you a bit to finish
The world looks very good on max settings
Music and sound effects, for the most part
Lots of collectibles which reward unique vehicles or weapons
ConsStory is as bland as it can get, and been done countless times before; same goes for the dialogue
Poorly optimized; beefy systems will stutter
Repetitive; not much variety to the bases or towns aside from new things being added (early bases may not have monitoring systems while later ones will, for example)
Main story and upgrades become gated behind the challenges, which make them necessary as opposed to optional
Character models are bland, and enemies all look alike (regular soldier looks like every other, armored one looks like every other armored soldier, etc.)
SummaryThe game is not without its issues. You could have a powerful system and still succumb to sub-30FPS without horrendous audio and visual stuttering. On the flip side, you could have a mid-range system and not have many issues at all.

Taken without its issues, Just Cause 3 is still a fun game. Itâ€™s best played in chunks, because the repetition will tire you if you were to play it for hours straight.

Finally, I recommend Just Cause 3 because when it works, itâ€™s pure fun. Thereâ€™s something to be said for arcadey games in todayâ€™s world, when a heavy focus is on strategy and realism, and with its insane explosions and aerial traversing, Just Cause 3 has arcadey in spades.

After a rocky launch i can finally give my full opinion on this game.

reviewText:
Summary: If you liked Just Cause 2, you will most likely enjoy Just Cause 3. If you're anything like me, you'll enjoy spending hours mindlessly dicking around with explosions, physics and stunts and this game gives you ample means to do so.

My impression is good so far, I'm having a lot of fun and I'm looking forward to spending lots of time messing around. If you buy this game expecting a deep and introspective work of art, look elsewhere. If you buy it and are looking for a fun game to experiment with and show your friends, this is the game for you.

Pros:
- Beautiful graphics and map design (love the vivid colors, lush landscapes and the sea is gorgeous.)
- Very fun gameplay (explosions, flying, and killing, oh my)
- Lots to work towards if you are a completionist
- Non-linear so you can progress past the missions or ignore them altogether after a point
- Lots of Easter Eggs
- Civilian cars can be captured and then ordered via black market supply drops
- Lots of models of cars, planes, tanks, and weapons to use
- Super corny voice-acting (JC staple)
- Sound effects are high quality
- Visual effects are stunning
- The new Wingsuit navigates really smoothly and is very fun once you get the hang of it

Cons:
- Occasional bugs (nothing game-breaking for me as of yet, but I've had to restart a few missions due to bugged objectives)
- Physics are wonky as hell (can be a pro in some cases, it's more geared towards fun than realism but mostly proves clunky and strange)
- Driving has some of the worst physics I've come across in any game (motorcycles are nearly impossible to drive)
- Moving rico around can be a hassle and interacting with vehicles or items can be a pain
- Not much depth story or character wise, but this is to be expected
- Always online can prove to be a nuisance if your connection is spotty (constant reconnection attempts)

All in all I am happy with my purchase and would recommend it to anyone considering it who knows what they are in for in a Just Cause game. I will update this review as I put in more hours.

Specs:
- i7-4790k
- 16 gb ram
- Nvidia 980
- Windows 8
- 7200 rpm HD
- 1440p monitor

Performance:
- Stable fps around 40-50 on very high settings @ 1440p
- Load times take around 10-20 seconds per cut scene (not ideal but it isn't on my ssd so it's expected)

Thanks for reading!

reviewText:
Just Cause 3 is by far the best game in the Just Cause series, and an absolute must-have for open world fans.


Story
In the story of Just Cause 3, you play as Rico Rodriguez, some sort of Spanish Rambo. Rico's massive open world home Medici is suffering under the typical dictator, who is oppressing his people, and threatens the whole world with his bavarium weapon production. It's obvious that the CIA is looking to get in on that too. Only Rico is in the way.


Gameplay
In the struggles against the dictator you must support the rebels of Medici by freeing over 130 villages, cities, outposts, oil rigs, and military camps by wreaking havoc. In addition to that, you must deal with countless singleplayer missions, challenges as well as sidequests.
For these tasks, you are provided with all sorts of weapons, vehicles, and gadgets. It's up to you whether you use a car, motorcycle, boat, plane, helicopter, parachute, wingsuit or your grappling hook for progression. The possibilities are endless.

Sadly the leveling system of Rico is both limited and almost pointless, since he is already very good at everything, but still you can unlock upgrade-mods" through completing challenges. These go all the way from target practice to racing.

reviewText:
Summary
Just Cause 3 has all the gadgets and exploding objects necessary to be a fun game, but it's been made into a frustrating experience. All of the fun stuff is hidden behind tens of hours of completing infuriating challenges and liberating repetitive military bases and villages.

Review
Just Cause 3 lacks any enjoyment during the first 50 hours of gameplay in my experience. It is not worth paying for such frustration, especially at full price. It took me 50 hours to lift the limitations placed on the player at the beginning of the game.

At the start of the game, I wanted to try exploding things in new ways, particularly with the new tethers, but they were disappointingly underpowered. The only way to improve tether strength and to get more than two of them was to liberate an ungodly amount of land. Eventually I unlocked the frustrating tether challenges. That took many boring hours. Although I now have fully upgraded tethers, I do not have the ability to enjoy them.

Another way Just Cause 3 stifles enjoyment is the fact that the player never has time to set up crazy destruction. The player will be killed by Di Ravello's army before they are able to successfully set up some elaborate, insane way to explode a statue using a car, tethers, and rocket powered C4. The number of potential ways to explode things are brilliant, but the number of opportunities to are not.

What really destroys the game's fun are challenges. They are how all gear mods are unlocked, from rocket powered C4 to multiple tethers. Gears are awarded based on the player's score, from one gear to five gears. The player needs a pretty high average score (3-4 out of 5) to unlock all gear mods in any category, such as car modifications.

What I first search for in every challenge is a way to complete it ASAP with a better vehicle or weapon, but that's not always possible. Fortunately, most challenges don't take too long. Unfortunately, there are some that seem impossible to score highly on, even with all weapons and vehicles unlocked. The wingsuit and destruction challenges are particularly infuriating. The former requires the player to fly perfectly through the center of several rings, without missing more than 1-3 (depending on the course length). The latter sometimes limits the player to weapons that are not suited to blowing s#!& up in 90 seconds, such as sniper rifles. Being somewhat of a perfectionist, attempting to unlock all gears felt like a waste of my life. That's a horrible feeling to have in any video game, and especially Just Cause.

The final modifications that can be unlocked for vehicles are the elimination of their cooldown timers, which is essential to have much of the fun in the game. Even the beloved wingsuit, an incredible method of transportation, has much of its functionality hidden behind challenges. The story and its individual missions are negligibly short, so it's up to the player to make their own fun with whatever Rico has. Without all of Rico's enhanced gadgetry, liberating the islands is a grind.

One instance when I was actually having fun was actively discouraged by the game, another time when the game annoyingly told me what I can play with and when. I was trying to liberate a base before disabling its bavarium nukes, and unsurprisingly it was taking a long time. I was enjoying getting constantly blown up by nukes while trying to fight an army and destroy their infrastructure. Suddenly I was spawned kilometers away, at the nearest base I liberated, rather than by the fun nuke time. I flew back a couple times only to get nuked and transported a few kilometers away. I was livid.

By the time I could use all of my gadgets and weapons with as much freedom as the game would offer, I was already 50 hours in. By that time, I had enough Just Cause 3. I did not feel like spending more time in its world with only a handful of different types of things to blow up that are arranged in many different ways. Maybe one day I will come back to this game and play it the way it should be, doing crazy nonsense.

I thank whoever reads this review and recommend them to play Just Cause 2 instead. It's much cheaper and has most of the same explosions and non-physics, plus it never made me frustrated. I could mess around all day there, without making any progress in the game.

reviewText:
I wish I could post a review with neither a thumb up nor a thumb down, because while it's cool and looks good, I still have a lot of gripes. There are some MAJOR problems that need to be addressed, but if not for them the game would be excellent and probably have a much higher average review rating. Since my experience with the crashes and problems that other users have been complaining about have been fairly rare, I'll be rating it positively, but considering how frequent they are among the playerbase in general I almost feel bad for doing so.

-Pros-
The explosions please my idiot monkey brain
Some parts of the environment, such as walls, now crumble when exploded
The new grapple/wingsuit etc mechanics are nice
The game is very pretty, especially underwater (as long as you don't look too closely at anything, it's pretty jarring in cutscenes to see every thread on Rico's shirt while the fence he's leaning against is blurry and pixelated)
-Neutral-
Car handling is different than in JC2, but arguably not for the better- cars aren't slippery TNT rockets made of paper mache any more, but they're also much slower and their turning feels somewhat unresponsive until you're suddenly pulling a hard turn that almost flips you (or just does)
I'm conflicted on Rico's new design for some reason. The change in his facial appearance, attitude, and way he talks- even though not changed on any fundamental level- feel like they've gone and replaced the original with a lookalike halfway through the film and expect us to not notice. Nothing meaningful, it's just a slight nag at the back of my mind during cutscenes that I just can't shake.
-Cons- (starting from arguably the worst)
People have been complaining about explosions crashing the game. This doesn't happen to me- instead, it crashes my entire PC every 10th time I throw a grenade. Even if nothing else is going on at the time.
I have 2 GTX980s in SLI and even I can't run this game on Ultra at a smooth 60fps. Have to turn most of the post-processing things (motion blur, depth of field, bokeh, SSAO, etc) off-- and all of them at once, not just one or the other-- in order to jump from ~40fps to ~120. That's... not good optimization. EDIT: The game apparently doesn't even support SLI, hence the unexpectedly poor performance.
The Online features can make it take AGES for the game to load at the start, in ADDITION to the annoyingly long intro video every time you play
There seem to be cutscenes every five seconds (at least at the beginning), and the directors have apparently never heard of changing camera angles without a complete fade to black between shots followed by a loading screen once the cutscene is actually over
The auto-snap on the grapple line is... annoying. It gets in the way and makes you frequently grab things you don't mean to.
You don't have very fine control over your movement, turning around and around in order to get a context action to show up (get in car, press button, etc) is more frequent than I'd prefer.
For a game all about explosions, they don't give you anywhere NEAR enough room to carry explosives.
I'll update this review as I play more & depending on how frequently the developer updates the game. Hopefully the devs fix the game-breaking problems quickly so I won't feel so bad about leaving a positive review.

reviewText:
I can't reccommend this game based on the state that the PC version is in.

A few months prior to this game releasing, the same studio released Mad Max.  That game had a fantastic PC version, and on my PC, I could run it at 1080p at 60 FPS with most settings maxed out.  It only took about 30 seconds from launching the game to playing it, and whenver the framerate would dip below 60, it would be clearly apparent why.

While Just Cause 3 is a somewhat more demanding game on a technical level (as shown by the slightly higher requirements), the game is nowhere near as well optimized.  On my PC, it would take about 15 minutes to make it to the main menu, unless you used some unofficial workarounds (putting Steam in offline mode, running the game as Admin, etc) that narrowed the wait down to about 5 minutes.  Once in the game, performance was ridiculously inconsistent.  I could manage about 30-40 FPS with most settings on low at the best case, with frequent game-breaking instances of slowdown to framerates so poor you could count the frames.  And while large physics events predictably had an impact on framerate, the worst instances of stuttering and slowdown were for seemingly random reasons.

While my machine is closer to the minimum specs than the recommended, there are plenty of people who have far better machines than mine who have reported similar issues.

At some point, this game will hopefully be the great game that it should be, but as of December 2015, I cant reccommend that someone pay $60 for a game that very well may have performance issues that are far more extreme than they should be on your machine.

reviewText:
I was looking forward to this game, not only for the game itself but because of the mod support they mentioned before launch.

A month or so after launch and I am still very disappointed with the game for many reasons.

It is optimised so bad. I'm running on a very good spec computer (see my profile for my full specs) and with lowered settings I average at about 50fps, but it's not consistent, it drops all the time or shoots up high which makes it really hard to play. Also putting on vsync (which is a must for me because of screen tear) causes the game to lock at a low fps if I dip under 60 which is really annoying.

The game itself is just horrible to play. The car handling is awful and the physics system is completely broken, everything explodes for no reason and things will flip about and act completely unnaturally. If you tether two things together then pull them in they will flip into the air, and the effect is seemingly worsened if one car is on fire.

The NPCs are useless. I don't even know how to describe how bad they are but just watch gameplay, you'll see what I mean.

The voice acting I've experienced so far is not what I would expect from such a big title, it is very amateurish and doesn't sound like it's from a professional game, it's quite immersion breaking when the game itself looks so good.

Load times are insane. I'm running the game on an SSD to try and speed it up, but it still takes ages to start for the first time and load into the level. It's really annoying that when I actually can be bothered to try and get my money out of the game and put up with all the problems it has to play for an hour or so, I have to sit in loading screens for ages to get there.

Finally, there is no official mod support, at least that I've heard of, so I'm not sure what they were on about when they mentioned modding before launch. Were they just implying that they were making the files easy to crack into to modify? If that's the case then that isn't exactly official mod support, that's just making a game using common formats.

Please fix this game, it has such potential but at the moment it's a mess. I would really not recommend buying until it's fixed, if it ever is.

reviewText:
Bullets and missiles whiz past my head as I speed through the night sky, surfing on a plane. The artillery of a whole nation seems to be focused on my annihilation, while I fire rocket after rocket at the ground below. The deafening roar of the engines and the air-sucking booms of coutless explosions are my soundtrack. If this was a film, it would be the movieâ€™s climax, when the hero does the impossible. In Just Cause 3, Avalancheâ€™s latest destruction-obsessed action romp, itâ€™s the opening scene.

For Rico Rodriguez, the gameâ€™s handsome, bearded protagonist â€“ a professional racer turned tyrant-toppler â€“ itâ€™s just another day at work. He blows up military bases for breakfast, and for lunch, he tears down bridges while the army of an evil dictator â€“ moustachioed cartoon villain Di Ravello â€“ drives across. Heâ€™s a one man army, a superhero in jeans, and heâ€™s done this all before. But this time, the explosions are bigger, the toys are more varied, and everything has just become a little bit more ridiculous.

I donâ€™t call Rico a superhero lightly. Avalancheâ€™s third destruction sandbox is as much a superhero game as Rocksteadyâ€™s Arkham series, at least when it comes to the action. Our leading man can take down entire armies, fly across islands, and even survive the explosion of a grenade. Once, while minding my own business, gliding across a mountain range, I was hit by a missile. I got back up again and stole a helicopter, which I then dropped on top of a tank. Iâ€™d like to see Batman attempt that.

With Just Cause 3, the writers have leaned directly into its b-movie comparisons. The story is a simple one, and is led by a host of zany, off the wall characters. Mario comedically  brings about numerous terrible ideasand spearheads one of the funnier missions in the game. Di Ravello is a compelling, but also by the books dictator. He hates everyone but himself, kills innocents, etc. For the most part, any type of cutscene in Just Cause 3 is forgettable. But I donâ€™t think anyone is expecting a philosophical masterpiece from a game that begins with its main character hanging upside down from a helicopter.

While little may have been expected of the story, it would be nice if the game built its story missions around using the strengths of the game. Missions often call for you to use your parachute/wingsuit combination in a variety of ways , but as the game went on, I found myself tiring of being forced to perform certain objectives. It felt as if I could do them by myself, without the help of the story, so there was no real reason to interact with them. The story feels like an afterthought to some of the more exciting stuff than can be found within Just Cause 3â€™s world.

Possibly the largest thing you will spend your time doing in Just Cause 3 is liberating the many cities of Medici. These areas of interest will typically contain a list of things that must be destroyed or taken over, such as a generator, billboard, radio tower, or police station. Though numerous, watching them explode is never tiring. Itâ€™s clear Avalanche Studios wants Just Cause 3 to be the kind of game you can sit down and have mindless fun with and these cities are good examples of just that. There were numerous times where I would get in the rhythm of taking over Medici and completely lost track of time. Itâ€™s just a great way to have fun watching all sorts of things explode into flames.

When you are not freeing the people of Medici, you will be probably be taking part in some of the many challenges strewn throughout the open world. These challenges are very reminiscent  to other open-world games and consist of car races, wing suit challenges, and the popular â€œblow everything up around youâ€ objectives. For the most part, these side challenges are just another way to kill some time and relax. They never become too difficult or complex, they simply exist as a way to focus the player on one of Just Cause 3â€™s mechanics. These missions can be easily overlooked if you want, but they do provide mods that can be helpful at times.

Just Cause 3â€™s new modification system adds some excitement to some areas of the game, while doing very little for others. As you earn more modifications for your grenades, you can have them explode on contact, or explode only when they connect with a certain object,be that an enemy, destructible object, etc.. The game also hides the ability to zoom in with weapons behind these modifications, but it is earned rather early on. While the mods available can provide some thrills, it does feel like there is some unexplored potential within the system.

The controls are basically fine. I didnâ€™t have any particular issues playing through on mouse and keyboard once I got used to the way everything worked, with the exception that vehicles (planes and the wingsuit, in particular) are a bit finicky on the keyboard because they really demand analogue controls. You might get a bit confused by the number of keys you need when swooping around â€“ right-click to grapple, Space to open/close parachute, Shift to accelerate your grapple, CTRL to disconnect your grapple, E to activate your wingsuit â€“ but I suspect thatâ€™d happen on a gamepad anyway, and I got used to it pretty fast.

The graphics and physics of this game are what gives form to the carnage that Rico unleashes upon his enemies, and they are impressive. At max settings the PC version is stunning, with an enormous draw distance and incredible detail at distances both close and afar. The physics engine is remarkably stable too, considering the shenanigans that you can instigate with the grappling hook and tethers. It also allows for some amazing destructibility, although when things get too crazy, the frame rate can take a dive as a consequence.

The game had network problems at various points in the time I was playing it. While an online connection is not required, you will always be logged in to Square Enixâ€™s servers at startup. When the connection is lost to these servers, the game comes to a crashing halt for 30 seconds as it tries to reconnect, regardless of whatever it is that you were in the middle of doing. Also the game has horrendous load times. Just Cause 3 has the worse load times of any game in years.

Gunplay in the Just Cause series has never been anything to brag about. That continues with Just Cause 3 as you never feel totally in  control when using a weapon.As for the actual gun selection, your options are varied. You can obtain all sorts of assault rifles as well as side arms. You constantly roll with a special weapon, which can range from your standard RPG to a gun that calls in airstrikes on whatever location you point it to. The variation in weapon sets makes destroying the many statues satellite dishes immensely satisfying.

When youâ€™re not waiting for it to load, Just Cause 3 is an incredibly fun game. Crisp visuals and a clever soundtrack bring all the explosions to life. Even with the violence and destruction, it manages to maintain a lighter tone than the Far Cry games, without sliding into the outright silliness of Saints Row. But, itâ€™s still silly enough. Dropping boats on satellite dishes, tying enemy soldiers to exploding gas tanks, and grappling, wingsuiting, and parachuting the length and breadth of beautiful Medici, just to blow the crap out of it. Just Cause 3 is an absolute blast.

reviewText:
I'm not gonna go on about performance issues (because I had extremely few of them) and I'm not gonna go on about precious elitist SLI support (because honestly, who really cares?). I am however gonna mention the extremely short main story and the serious lack of content in this game.

There's absolutely nothing to do after you finish the main story line. Sure, I could do a about a hundred arbitrary repetitive challenges but where's the fun in that? They're all the same. reviewText:
Let's face it: the game is horribily HORRIBLY optimized. Even with my quite good build, I hemorrhage ram like crazy unless I turn everything down. As of right now it wont even SLI correctally. So basically, I play on low-medium settings so that I don't experience framerate issues, but even then I get sometimes some drops, and whats the fun in having a HIGH end computer to play a game (you havto pay moneys for) to play on medium.....

Anyways:
Pros
1) The game, even if I play on low settings, looks good. It's colorful, bright, smooth, and the explosions are incredibly enjoyable
2) The sounds are ok, and the voice actors are really funny and well done.
3) I liked the music, even though they are quiet and you don't really hear them.
4) The gameplay is fun and addictive. I love the wingsuit, I enjoy moving through the mountains with my gears, the shooting is fun. Though I had to remap a bit my controls because I wanted it to feel like Just Cause 2, it plays well, and it is fun.
5) The explosions and the grappling hook... Nothing else to say, it's just well done. The game become somewhat a physics-based game with the ability to use your grappling.
6) Huge map, a lot of places to blow up.
7) The leaderboard thigie is neat (i dont care if im not as good as my friends)

Cons
1) You won't give a crap about the story/missions, as for Just Cause 2.
2) The map is too big. Yes, I said it was a pro, but my main problem is when you try to go from an island to the other. If you don't have a jet, it'll take forever to crosse the water.
3) I still don't get how the chaos work for this episode - might change this point once I figure it out.
4) As stated above,
5) the optimization,
6) IS
7) ABSOLUTLY
8) POSITIVELY
9) HORRRRRRIIIIIIIDDDDD
10) Having to log into Square Enix servers for everything, so if their down the game props you every few minutes, or every time you open the map
11) Initial Load times, the main menu--game start is dreadful, and yes i've heard of the SSD vs HDD
12) Gets repetitive quickly

Conclusion
Overall, this game is a fun experience, if you like blowing things up and killing people like there is no tomorrow (which is my case so...). If you want deep story, dark intrigue, multiplayer mode or realistic gunfight, just ignore this game. I think that if you liked Just Cause 2, you'll like this one too. It's no where near perfect, it surely isn't as good as JC2, but it's fun, and it gives you explosion, so it's nice.

reviewText:
Ah Just Cause 3, a good game? A bad game? A fun game? A boring game?...  If these were statements instead of questions they'd all be true of JC3. This is a game of systems and mechanics and what is there works great, however I think sadly there isn't enough mechanics to keep the game interesting all of the time.

A typical play session of JC3 would be travel some where and blow everything up, then rinse and repeat. It doesn't matter why you're there and the context of your destruction, that is what it boils down to, explosions. Now nearly every game ever made could be described in such over simplified terms and I know that, but what JC3 fails to do is disguise this fact in a way that you don't realise that is all your doing.

Now don't get me wrong, how you go about exploding everything around you is immense fun. Grenades, rockets, grenade launchers, high jacking Tanks, combat Helicopters, fighter jets, using grappling hooks to pull down structures, topple fuel tanks etc etc...  it goes on and on and it also looks really good too, the explosions in particular are something to behold. They have made this a spectacle and it is awesome to see, at least for a while.

Like with any spectacle, it has a shelf life, you can't watch fireworks for 30 hours straight and not get bored, but in small bursts here and there... fireworks are great! That pretty much sums up the game for me, good in small bursts but it does get tired quickly over an extended play period.

Does this make it a bad game? Not in my book, but it does make it a shallow game and sadly an imperfect experience. Difficulty isn't high (which I am fine with by the way) so the challenge will come from destroying things in the most spectacular way or efficient way you can think of.

The story missions are ok and the final boss is an expected anti climax, but there is a narrative if you're interested. There is loads to do, upgrades to unlock, challenge missions that test your skills and collectables, you aren't short of content but like me you might find yourself asking if you *want* to do it all...  as I said,  you'll be more or less doing the game thing over and over again in a very noticeable way which at times felt like a chore.

It is what it is, it never advertised itself as anything other than a fun explosive romp, so no complaints that it delivered on it's promise, but whether that will be enough for you or not, will boil down to own personal tastes.

reviewText:
Alright, here's what I think. After 43 hours and almost completely liberating everything in just under a week, I have to admit I like it and it's a ton of fun. It's everything I wanted from the next instalment in the franchise.

I have heard some people complain that there's not much content beyond liberating bases and completing challenges. This is true, but then I think that Just Cause 2 was exactly the same, and everyone loved that.

Next thing is complaints about stuff being locked behind challenges. Personally, I do not mind this, I already get more than what I got in vanilla Just Cause 2 (unlimited explosives, multiple tethers). So getting more is technically optional (although I do recommend it, it makes the game significantly easier). Just try to do the challenges. They may seem repetitive but each one is just about fresh enough in my humble opinion.

There is *one* thing that bothers me to no end though and that is the  always online feature. It often disconnects me from the servers, making me often have to reconnect, sometimes it won't reconnect and I have to go into offline mode where it will try to reconnect me every 5 minutes when I pause the game as well. I know you want to keep your game out of the hands of those pesky pirates and I respect that but at least make sure that the people who do purchase it are not inconvenienced by your measures.

That said, the game runs fairly well on my set-up with I7-4790K, GTX 770 and 16 GB of RAM. Running it on high and maintaining 60 FPS most of the time. FPS drops are present but rather rare.

I personally would give this game a solid 8.5/10.

reviewText:
Starting to get VERY fed up with devs releasing unfinished games. The game itself is brilliant, it just runs like a pig. I don't have a high spec system, but I can run SW: Battlefront on High at a solid 60fps. This turd is so unoptimised and poorly coded that it ran at 60fps on high last night, then tonight it ran ok but crashed. After restarting it cant even reach 20fps with the same settings. Even with everything on low or off it's still EXACTLY the same frame rate.
The lip snch goes out on every single cut scene, then catches up, then goes again.
The frame rate goes from 60 to 20 randomly for no reason, but during massive explosions and shed loads of chaos on screen, it mostly copes fine. I'd expect with this amount of stuff going on it will drop of a few frames when things hot up, but it doesn't do too badly. It just randomly slows down with no obvious reason.
So dissapointed as it seems like a really good game.
Just cannot recommend it until they've fixed it. But then I thought that about Arkham Knight...

Just to clarify on a few points -

My system exceeds the minimum specs. Why would I complain about a game that runs badly if I dont meet the minimum specs.....? As I said, I changed everything to the lowest settings and it still ran the same, whereas the day of release it was on high and ran fine.

I do know whats involved with coding a game. What I also understand is that money men get int he way of deveopment and demand the game is released before its been fully bug tested. It happens all the time. A few games are managed really well and make it out the door brilliantly - SW: Battlefront being the best example I've ever seen. And no, I wouldn't say JC3 is any more demanding specs wise than Battlefront. Yes, JC3 has more explosions and is a tiny bit more CPU intensive, but have you seen Battlefront on high settings? It's flippin beautiful. But more importantly, this is a AAA game made by experienced devs a good few years into a console's life, and with previous PC experience, I expected more.

As for the running like a pig similie - i'd look up the word first if I were you. It's a figure of speech. And yes pigs do run quite quick, but when did you last see them running consistently for a long period? Hence the fairly accurate simile....

Also I never said it was easy to make video games. But DICE managed it without lousy code with Battlefront. Yes lots of games are released these days with game breaking bugs - I still cant play Fallout 4 in my native resolution due to a bug and Arkham Knight still isnt fixed. But this will keep happening if we all just keep accepting it and saying, Oh well
date:
it'll be fixed at some point I suppose..."

I did also say that the game itself seemed great. If they do fix all the bugs quickly I'd recommend the game wholeheartedly - I'm really enjoying what I can play of it.

And lastly - no game should be released with this many bugs. Yes I understand that many arent having problems - but many are and it seems to be the code at fault - not many complaints can be put down to rigs not meeting minimumspec/driver updates etc."

reviewText:
UPDATED!
So while my initial reaction was that this game was fully broken on release (and it kinda was) its been, partially, fixed now, at least when it comes to some of the direct technical issues. The game is running much smoother and i'm getting a almost stable 60 fps at everything maxed, for the most part, at certain times  (seems kinda random)  it will drop to unacceptable numbers (25-40) but for the most part its a steady 55-60. It still needs some work though.

The game itself looks great at times, but also quite bad at times. Overall the graphics are good, the environment is nice and colorful, but then at certain times (such as during night and during rain weather) it will look quite bad, as if there was some kind of blue/grayish filter applied. Water looks good up close, but quite poor at a distance.

The good parts of this game, from what i've played so far, is definitely the improved parachute and wingsuit. This is well made and enjoyable to use. The grappling hook could definitely use an improved reach though, as you cannot grapple that far. I was sure that this was one of the unlocks (as you upgrade your equipment) but turns out it wasn't. Thats kind of disappointing, i guess i'll have to wait for a modder to fix that. Wingsuit and parachute are fine though, and are an improvement over Jc2.

Whats not good, in fact very far from good, is the driving. The cars and bikes handling is very poor. The controls feel awkward and sluggish, and the physics are really terrible. Those of you who, like myself spent quite some time in Jc2, know that it wasn't exactly praised for its car handling back then either, but its actually a big step down from there. This is quite sad, as i'm pretty certain that this is not something they will work on. The devs have acknowledge that the game isn't perfect and they've said they will be working on improving certain things. As of know we don't know when the next patch is coming, and while i do trust that the developers are looking to solve certain problems (such as the lack of fov & camera options which is a huge problem atm), i just do not think that there is any easy fix to the handling & physics of cars, it would probably require a complete overhaul that will not happen after the game is released.

I'm not very far into this (and usually i do spend more time before writing a review) so i'm not finished with the story, but from what i can tell its pretty much the same as Jc2, ie its not good at all. The voice acting and characters are maybe not as cringe as in Jc2, but they are still pretty bad. In a wider sense, the gameplay is very arcady, possibly even more than it was in Jc2. Some will like this, some will not. Personally i think they could've had a little more serious tone to it. I don't mind that its arcady and unrealistic, its just a tad bit too much for my taste.

That doesn't matter too much though, since you are most likely getting this for the open-world sandbox experience. Speaking of the world, the map seems to be huge, i'm not sure if its bigger than the map of Jc2, but its definitely bigger than Gtav.  I've spent some time flying around in high speed aircrafts (which sadly also handles very poorly) and i've not yet even seen half of the entire map.

So, am i recommending this or not?  I do wish that steam offered a third option, other than just yes and no, because my answer is yes & no.  The game definitely has potential. However, it seems its still not running well or at all for a lot of people, and even if you get it running, the experience is not as good as it should be. I think they should've polished it more before releasing it. I suggest you wait  a while for them to patch it, as well as some mods to come out. Therefor i'm not changing this review to positive, yet.

I'm disappointed, Avalanche.

The game looks and sounds great - but poor performance (hopefully this will be patched) and lack of multi-GPU support is a big let down. reviewText:
The main problem with this game is the graphics and character control.  The graphics are just plain bad.  It looks like it would be at home on PS3, which was great...eight years ago.
The character's movements, especially in combat, don't feel very up to date either.  It's one of those things where you can run around too easily while taking heavy gunfire from several enemies that don't move or take cover or act at all like actual people.
Driving and flying are also quite poor. It's basically identical to Just Cause 2, which was good in its time but that time has passed.
Also my pc surpasses the recommended specs yet I still run into choppy gameplay at times.  I play several other games that were released recently on the highest graphical settings with no problem and they look a hell of a lot better than this, so I'm inclined to believe it's either poor programming or a collection of bugs.
To throw some positive light on this poorly executed game I must say that the gameplay is enjoyable.  Who doesn't like an open world where everything can be victim to exploding?  Also the improvements with the grappling hook make for some fun and unique ways to destroy things and kill enemies.
All in all it's really too bad that the graphics and character control ruined what was an excellent idea for a game.

reviewText:
There's a good game buried under here somewhere, but it's not worth playing at the moment.

Apparently people with nVidia cards haven't had as many issues issues, so you might be good to go if you have one. But if you have an AMD card, you're rolling the dice. Better off waiting to see if they fix their game.

reviewText:
Just Cause 2 is a really good game. I really want to love Just Cause 3, but I can't. It's probably my most regretted purchase of a game. The multi grapple is great, and the more detailed destruction physics are a blast. Aside from that, it is a much worse game than JC2.

The controls are an absolute abomination, the vehicle and movement physics are atrocious, and the game has one of the worst cases of multiple-bound controls ever with no way to fix it despite having plenty of buttons on PC. Avalanche clearly knew this, because they made everything very sticky and semi-automated to try and compensate for it instead of fixing the underlying problems. The result is the most frustrating experience imaginable, spending most of your time stuck in animations or an out of control vehicle wishing you could do the simple, cool thing you want to do. Just go watch some youtube videos of someone blowing up a few bases and you'll get 95% of the fun of this game without any of the frustration.

Possibly the single worst thing is that the one thing that does work right, the wingsuit, is deliberately gimped. Pitching up is extremely weak compared to all the other inputs, which eliminates the possibility for skillfully skimming just above the ground - especially combined with another feature"

reviewText:
Do NOT buy this game in its current state. I would rarely give such strong criticism but on a technical level this game is broke as f*ck.
I've been a huge fan of the Just Cause series for 6 or 7 years now, and JC2 was probably some of the most fun I've ever had in a game. JC3 takes everything that is great about the series and in most cases IMPROVES on it, with one catch: the game runs like absolute crap. Look at the thousands of other reviews here to see this is far from an isolated issue. I'm running on a GTX 760 (would be two if SLI was even supported...), getting a little dated now but by no means a terrible card. And yet with all graphics on the lowest settings there's still stuttering and FPS drops into the single digits every few seconds.

It's such a huge shame because on the rare occassion that the gameplay isn't destroyed by FPS drops, horrible stuttering, or just flat out grinding to a halt, there is clearly an amazing game with dozens of hours of explosion-fuelled fun hiding underneath.

I will update this review to positive when the devs actually do their job and release a game that actually works (I thought that was their job to begin with...?), however long it may take for patches and drivers to fix this broken game. Just another example of the sorry state of modern video games: release a sh*tty, broken game now; patch later.

reviewText:
I REALLY want to like this game, but at the moment I really don't think it's worth 60 dollars. I've spent a little time with the game and I like some of the core functions of the game. It looks beautiful and almost every core function is an upgrade over Just Cause 2. Driving is much improved over the last game, but still doesn't hold a candle to the driving in something like GTA and I don't feel like there is a huge variety for land vehicles like there were in JC2. There are a lot of tacked on things that I don't enjoy: namely the whole gear and upgrade system. I feel like some of the game is essentially locked down until the player does all these gimmicky challenges that are pretty much bs. The rebel drop system has issues too, there are too many restrictions on it; you need to have a certain amount of beacons and on top of that, each vehicle has a cooldown. The developers should have implemented one or the other seeing as it's very common for dropped vehicles to just self destruct. The game also has some unsatisfactory performance on my system. I'm running an 8150 and a 780 which should more or less satisfy the requirements, however my gpu is under-utilized (running 60-70% gpu usage as shown by MSI Afterburner) and I get framerates anywhere from the low 30s to high 50s. My settings are mostly set to high, with shadows on medium, no AA and motion blur off. My advice would be to wait until someone makes a mod to bypass the challenges and maybe then consider the game. Personally I will keep playing it because I can't refund it at this point and the game is ok. If you see it anywhere for less than 40 bucks I think that is a worthwhile price, but I can't recommend this game at the full 60 dollar price.

EDIT: I'ver found some mods that adress my issues with the gameplay: http://justcause3mods.com/mods/unlock-all-gear-mods/ http://justcause3mods.com/mods/no-rebel-drop-timers/ http://justcause3mods.com/mods/no-intro/ http://justcause3mods.com/mods/infinite-beacons/ . Game is still isn't perfect and I'm still getting some notably iffy performance, I still think it's not worth 60 dollars, but these mods make the game so much more fun to play.

EDIT2: A ton of mods were broken last month including some of the ones I linked. Game performance is still meh at best. Don't pay the full $60.

reviewText: Overall, the game is great. The scenery looks beautiful, the weapons look and sound better than in the previous games, the vehicles actually handle much better, and even the aircraft no longer have that stupid left banking tendency like in the last game. You can't even run max settings on a stable FPS unless your PC build has something like an i7-5820k and an NVidia Titan. Most people don't have that kind of cash to dump into the game. I strongly recommend removing the DRM anti-piracy system for starters. Yes, it's good to prevent piracy, but the game and the sales are now suffering even worse because of that hungry system, all in an effort to prevent the studio from losing sales (ironic). Furthermore, I think the leaderboard system is something that no one really pays attention to. Avalanche, please remove that too and allow the third party devs of JC2MP do their work. reviewText:
Just cause 3 is different to JC2. If you take that on board you'll have more fun!

I really like JC3 although it does have flaws. The wingsuit is amazing, exploring the map is an enjoyable experience and experimenting with the mechics is endlessly hilarious. There's plenty of things to do and I found the game easily ate up 50+ hrs while liberating all the settlements, completing the storyline and getting all the collectables.

Once you've done all that you're kinda left to your own devices. Unless you actively enjoy experimenting with the mechanics of the game, or happen to enjoy stunts there's not an awful lot left to do. You can reinstate individual locations and liberate them again but it's a little bit of an empty process with no goal. As a single player open world game this is a huge mistake not to add some kind of value to the game after it has been completed (DLC is on it's way but we don't have any idea of what content it will provide yet)

This is just the tip of the iceberg when it comes to flaws. There's design decisions that leave me baffled: no FOV slider or choice of camera angles (I think they ran out of control pad buttons to use lol), assigning boost to different buttons depending on the type of vehicle you're in. The weird delay you get between stunt jumping on a vehicle and being able to grapple. The main island being virtually empty. The dumb AI. The crashing. The list goes on and on. The lack of keybindings. Jeez I could talk about the flaws for a LONG time as there are so many and they really do effect the expereince negatively.

Having said all that, I'm a huge fan of the Just CAuse franchise and the possibilities the game yields. As such I'm ok with overlooking the flaws. I spend a lot of my time stunting or creating silly experiments in JC3 and it's easily been worth the money paid. Will you enjoy it as much? I'm not sure... I suppose it depends how you play games. If you follow the missions and complete the story before moving on you may miss a lot about what makes JC3 so unique and enjoyable. However if you're more creative with your gameplay then you'll likely get a lot more from the experience.

Either way I'm looking to the future now as the DLC shall be here soon (hopefully with more map content) and the JC2MP Team are working on a multiplayer mod for Just Cause 3.... which will change EVERYTHING!

reviewText:
Rico Rodriguez is back!

First, I have to admit I am a JC fanboy, this game got me since the first installment. Dunno why but I found the gamedesign, phantasmagoric (ab)use of grappling hook in particular very entertaining. I spent dozens maybe hundreds of hours just flying across San Esperito or Panau if you like, setting on fire anything which could have been set on fire, destroying anything which could have beed destroyed. When JC3 was announced I was happy and was looking forward.

I was very surprised when I noticed that reviews of JC3 are mixed mostly due technical issues, but it is understood. To be honest, there are no technical problems for me, I am the lucky one. After 60 hours of playing I have got just one single crash, that is it. Everything is smooth and rock solid. But I do not deny there are some issues just because I do not have one.

JC3 story is bland but c'mon, JC has never been about the story, it is pure madness full of explosions and silly travelling across the huge map.

Gameplay is what a fan of JC franchise could have wished for - grappling hook, explosion, some racing, shooting explosion again, grappling hook, missile ride, shooting, grappling hook, explosion, shooting, explosion, grappling hook... Oh, did I mention the grappling hook?

I am not disappointed, this game is true JC as I remembe and love. For the fans of JC it is must have. For the others - well, I would say try JC2 first, if you love it you will love JC3 too. If not then hands off, there is nothing new except some small but handy improvements (wingsuit!).

I hope there are still some nasty dictators in the virtual world who need to be overthrown by Rico in the future! :)

reviewText:
This review is based on the game itself and not the technical issues such as the very high GPU and RAM usage which can cause stutters on even high-end machines, with AMD users in particular suffering from this. Hopefully this problem will be patched soon.

Just Cause 3 is basically just Just Cause 2 but with added improvements including a grapple that can tether more than once and can retract, allowing the player to tear down structures or attach two enemies together. There are a good variety of weapons and vehicles ranging from mortars to nuke launchers and tanks with energy shields, there are plenty to fuel your destruction.

Compared to Just Cause 2, the weapons and vehicles are better (although lack of a Tuk-Tuk Boom is disappointing) and the grapple and wingsuit add new dimensions. As a base game, Just Cause 3 is just Just Cause 2 with a new map and more to play with, unlike how Just Cause 2 was a complete makeover compared to the first Just Cause.

Is it worth full price? I don't think so, although I bought this game off â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ for Â£17 and got a free game as a bonus. For Â£17 this game is definitely worth it.

The upcoming DLC including Sky Fortress certainly looks fun, I'll make a review for the DLC when each is released.

Overall, if you are expecting a game completely better than Just Cause 2, then this is not it. If you are a person who hasn't played a Just Cause game before, then this is a brilliant game to play. For a price like Â£39.99 it is not worth it for any interested party, although considering I got it for Â£17 off from â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥, it is best to get it from there and the price is getting cheaper all the time.

reviewText:
Let's face it: the game is badly optimized. With my quite good build, I ram like crazy unless I turn everything down. So basically, I play on low-medium settings so that I don't experience framerate issues, but even then I get sometimes some drops.
EDIT:
Since the recent patch it's much better, as I can run it in full-medium settings (and 1080p) without any framerate issue, so that's a big plus.

Now let's review itI'll do my usual thing, a pros and cons list.

Pros1) The game, even if I play on low settings, looks good. It's colorful, bright, smooth, and the explosions are incredibly enjoyable
2) The sounds are ok, and the voice actors (for the french version at least) are really funny and well done.
3) I liked the musics, even though they are quiet and you don't really hear them.
4) The gameplay is fun and addictive. I love the wingsuit, I enjoy moving through the mountains with my gears, the shooting is fun. Though I had to remap a bit my controls because I wanted it to feel like Just Cause 2, it plays well, and it is fun.
5) The explosions and the grappling hook... Nothing else to say, it's just well done. The game become somewhat a physics-based game with the ability to use your grappling.
6) Huge map, a lot of places to blow up.
7) I don't have any problem with this leaderboard thing, I find it fine and a good thing, to compare yourself with other people.

Cons1) You won't give a crap about the story, as for Just Cause 2.
2) The map is too big. Yes, I said it was a pro, but my main problem is when you try to go from an island to the other. If you don't have a jet, it'll take forever to crosse the water.
3) I still don't get how the chaos work for this episode - might change this point once I figure it out.
4) As stated above, the optimization, it's still not great, but they are working on it.

ConclusionOverall, this game is a fun experience, if you like blowing things up and killing people like there is no tomorrow (which is my case so...). If you want deep story, dark intrigue, multiplayer mode or realistic gunfight, just ignore this game. I think that if you liked Just Cause 2, you'll like this one too. It's not perfect, it surely isn't as good as JC2, but it's fun, and it gives you explosion, so it's nice.

BEFORE ANYONE ASK FOR MY CONFIG:
Intel Core i7 4970k quadcore 3.6GHz
16Go DDR3 RAM
Nvidia GTX960 with 2Go GDDR5
And I run on Windows 10

reviewText: As I write this review I currently have played 53 hours over the past week since launch, and I believe this is enough time to make an accurate review. This game brings all the great things that we all loved from Just Cause 2 and more, I cannot reccommend it enough. Overall this is a great game and has many amazing features that solidify this game as my favourite game of the year even taking top spot over the Witcher 3: WIld Hunt. reviewText:
https://youtu.be/i0hWDulibkU
Game: Just Cause 3
Genre: Open World Action
Developer: Avalanche Studios
Publisher: Square Enix
Copy supplied by Steam

Just Cause 3 is an open world action game developed by Avalanche Studios and published by Square Enix.

STORYYou play again as Rico Rodriguez, member of the Agency, and this time he goes back to his hometown, Medici, to help his childhood friends and the rebellion get rid of Colonel DiRavello, an evil dictator who has made life miserable for everyone.
The story isn't all that different from the other games of the serie, but this time I was more invested in it: the characters are more fun, there are more over-the-top set-pieces, and I was having a genuine good time. It might not win an Oscar for best screenplay, but it works for the game just fine.

GRAPHICSAMD users are currently having serious issues with this game. I recommend waiting for a patch before buying it.
Avalanche knows how to make a good looking open world: the islands and mountains of Medici look gorgeous, and each town and base is beautiful to blow up in an orchestra of explosions. The physics are also improved and both more realistic and fun, and more objects can be destroyed, including bridges. The performance was mostly pretty good (45fps on an average laptop) and the game crashed only once while recording with Fraps. It's mostly been a stable experience.
The character model of Rico finally looks badass, especially because of the beard. The only real complaint I have is related to everyone else: the NPCs are not very detailed and can get repetitive pretty fast. Still, it looks amazing and it was very relaxing to wingsuit from a mountaintop into the ocean.

GAMEPLAYWhen playing Just Cause 3, you must know what you are getting into. It's a game that wants to deliver an open world filled with enemy bases and cities in which you must destroy propaganda billboards, fuel tanks, antennas and radars. And the game completely delivers in that.
This is basically an improved version of Just Cause 2: the shooting feels smoother, you can actually walk on vehicles even while driving, you can pull tethered objects, the driving is (slightly) better, and the missions are a bit more fun. They even got completely rid of QTEs, and you can call Rebel Drops with vehicles and weapons without using any money. To move around the environment you have cars, tanks, jets and boats, as well as the grappling hook, parachute and a really fast and useful wingsuit that makes running away from bad situations very easy.
Other than story missions, you can destroy outposts or complete Challenges. Each Challenge is related to a different gameplay area (shooting, driving, destroying), and you get Gears that unlock new modifications to improve Rico: carry more grenades, tether more objects, fast Rebel Drops deployments... Thus you get rid of annoying weapon and vehicle upgrades, making the game just less frustrating to play.
The game is as boring as you want it to be: you can just shoot rockets and bullets at everything, or try to tether a car packed of explosives to a sphere tank and watch it all blow up in glorious fashion. You make your experience fun or boring.

CHALLENGEThe game is mostly challenging while trying to get an high score in Challenges or in some bases with tight security. The AI isn't all that polished, and sometimes might shoot at nothing, but they did manage to kill me a couple of times, especially when I was trying to look cool.

SOUNDThe soundtrack is fairly good and the sound effects are as always top notch. The voice acting is also the perfect blend of cheesy and self-aware, and I laughed a couple of times during the cutscenes because of some delivery (especially from Mario).

REPLAYABILITY1000 kmÂ² of playground, 47 Steam achievements (mostly about Story missions and 100% completion), plenty of challenges and endless possibilities to cause chaos will keep you entertained for many hours to come.

Overall, I find this to be a vary damn fun video game. If you enjoyed Just Cause 2 and open world games, the game is pretty much the same and there is plenty of content to keep you hooked. However, some of you might find the whole experience repetitive and tedious. But adrenaline junkies and fans of over-the-top action movies will feel fantastic, going from base to base blowing everything up.

Story: 7
Graphics: 9
Gameplay: 9
Challenge: 8
Sound: 9
Replayability: 9

ENJOYMENT: 9
FRUSTRATION: 4

Just Cause 3
The Game Just Cause 3 is accexeptably great. I would recomend it for all who love games that you can have freedom to use weapons of mass destruction and enjoyable vehicles in an open world.

This is a great game, very stunning, this includes the vehicles, Rico himself and just the world.  The weapons are great, flying around is fun, pretty easy to get used to the controls. Some downsides to this game is that it is very short, it is easy to finish and liberate all of the areas. Also the motorbike controls are horrible on both keyboard and controller. Back to the main point, should you get this. If you have Just Cause 2, then yes, it's a good sequel. If you don't have Just Cause 2 and you are not sure if you will like this seris, then get Just Cause 2. If your computer sucks, then Just Cause 2. But if you have the money and a great PC, then i highly reccomend you get this game, it is fun to mess around and beat your friends on the in-game leaderboard.

reviewText:
Another great game from Avalanche Studios that can make even Michael Bay feel jealous!

This time the action takes place in Medici, an archipelago with a mediterranean look where everything seems to be latinized. The voice acting of most characters is done with an italian accent and sometimes they sound funny. Even the PSAs that you hear on the radio after liberating a base are hilarious.

The game doesn't take itself too seriously. Story is generic, just as expected, but you are here for the action and to blow stuff up - and that is where the game shines. Explosions look awesome with nice particle effects and Rico Rodriguez, the one-man-army, has a lot of creative ways to make things go BOOM. You can use a wide variety of guns and vehicles, but some of your best and most fun toys unlock later in the game.

The open-world is filled with optional activities and collectibles, but there is some grinding involved if you want to unlock all the mods. Although the open-world is huge, there are a lot of useless green areas like forests or fields that make for long travelling times between objectives (until fast travel is unlocked).

Unfortunately the game is not very well optimized for PC and the physics engine acts unexpected sometimes. If you are hoping for another Mad Max then you'll be disapointed because this game requires a high-end machine to run smooth. There is an always-online component that makes the game stutter. Also, found one game breaking bug in a main story mission so I would suggest to wait for further patches that will hopefully improve optimisation and fix all issues.

Overall: I had a fun time with Just Cause 3 and I recommend it if you like open-world action games.

Viva Medici!

reviewText:
Much as I loved this game when I first started playing it (got 45hrs on it at the time of writing), I have to say my enthusiasm's starting to wane a bit now due to some of the glitches and design decisions. That said, hopefully the patch, when it comes, will address some of these...

1) If you're used to the parachute controls in JC2 and the JC2MP mod, you're going to find the parachute handles very differently in JC3. Whilst it feels a lot more realistic, it's a lot slower and less responsive in its handling in JC3, so I find myself having to crunk my way around, which is tedious by comparison to JC2's parachute handling. I know there's a wingsuit, but try flying very tight turns between city buildings in the wingsuit and staying aloft.

2) The land vehicle handling has been commented on by other posters - slow to start turning, then turns very sharply. I know JC2's vehicles had very sensitive handling, but at least it was fairly linear, so you could get used to the sensitivity after a while. The overall handling in JC3 is also less responsive, less fun as far as I can see.

3) The failure to respond to control input which dogged JC2 and the MP mod is still apparent in JC3. Some of it is because Rico's busy doing something else with his hands (reloading, etc), but I've had plenty of times where Rico's just completely ignored the first two or three button presses while doing absolutely nothing else. The worst instance is when trying to place C4 on the underside of a chopper that's airborne - on one occasion, I had to hit the mouse button about 10 times to get him to finally place the explosive.

4) Some of the missions are really quite badly put together. Again, maybe a patch would add a bit of polish, but as one example, having to push one of the NPCs 25 metres to persuade them to get onto a chopper so the mission could end isn't hugely impressive.

On the plus side:

a) Even on my crusty rig (i5-750, GTX 750Ti, 8GB RAM and an SSD), the game looks pretty good with some of the settings turned down, and it runs well in terms of frame-rate (though there are occasional slowdowns and the odd crash to desktop).

b) The wingsuit has a steep learning curve, and the handling still needs work IMO, but it's a lot of fun :-)

c) There's a good choice of weapons, and the tanks are great for shooting up bases from nearby hillsides without even being detected :-)

I like JC3 a lot, and I'm optimistic the patch might help improve things further, but after more than 400hrs on JC2, and more than 900hrs on JC2MP, I still think it could have been better.

reviewText:
Buy this damn game.

I'll get my main complaint out of the way - the map feels empty. Just Cause 2 also felt empty, especially in the cities, but there were always settlements to be found. Now, the bottom half of the map is a strikingly beautiful paradise that you could get lost in for hours. As the game progresses, you travel North to confront the dictator and find...nothing. The rolling fields give way to endless mountians, with one or two military settlements populating the area. From a story perspective, it makes sense, but it just feels lacking. I also wish we could replay missions. After the campaign is over, I found myself missing the comedic voices of the supporting characters over the radio, and several memorable missions plunged the entire island into war. It sucks that I can't recapture flying through the air, staring down at firefights erupting all over the island. I can't express how dope that was. Instead, now I'm stuck liberating the final settlements, and using the game as the destructive sandbox it was meant to be played as.

What a sandbox though. They improved driving to the level where it's almost satisfying. The graphics are truly amazing. Gunplay is remarkably fun, and it functions like a legitimate third person shooter. Stunts were given more thought, and now you have a wingsuit that you can fly through the map with. You can spawn any vehicle, at any place, for free. It's like the devs took every small nitpick with Just Cause 2, and fixed it all. I can't think of another game where I could tether two oil drums together, and wait for a soldier to walk between them before yanking them together to blow everything up. It's Micheal Bay: The Game. Buy it, have fun with it. One of the most entertaining games I've ever played.

The game itself isn't too bad, it's basically Just Cause 2 but with some new weapons, gadgets and vehicles on a new map. If you really want to pay Â£40 for practically more of the same but with bugs and unbearable 'always online' features then go ahead but if not, wait for them to remove the annoying reconnection issues and get it on a steam sale.

reviewText:
My impression is good so far, I'm having a lot of fun and I'm looking forward to spending lots of time messing around. If you buy this game expecting a deep and introspective work of art, look elsewhere. If you buy it and are looking for a fun game to experiment with and show your friends, this is the game for you.

Pros:
- Beautiful graphics and map design (love the vivid colors, lush landscapes and the sea is gorgeous.)
- Very fun gameplay (explosions, flying, and killing, oh my)
- Lots to work towards if you are a completionist
- Non-linear so you can progress past the missions or ignore them altogether after a point
- Lots of Easter Eggs
- Civilian cars can be captured and then ordered via black market supply drops
- Lots of models of cars, planes, tanks, and weapons to use
- Super corny voice-acting (JC staple)
- Sound effects are high quality
- Visual effects are stunning
- The new Wingsuit navigates really smoothly and is very fun once you get the hang of it

Cons:
- Occasional bugs (nothing game-breaking for me as of yet, but I've had to restart a few missions due to bugged objectives)
- Physics are wonky as hell (can be a pro in some cases, it's more geared towards fun than realism but mostly proves clunky and strange)
- Driving has some of the worst physics I've come across in any game (motorcycles are nearly impossible to drive)
- Moving rico around can be a hassle and interacting with vehicles or items can be a pain
- Not much depth story or character wise, but this is to be expected
- Always online can prove to be a nuisance if your connection is spotty (constant reconnection attempts)

All in all I am happy with my purchase and would recommend it to anyone considering it who knows what they are in for in a Just Cause game. I will update this review as I put in more hours.

Specs:
- i7-6600k
- 16 gb ram
- Nvidia 980ti G1 Gaming
- Windows 10
- 7200 rpm HD
- 1080p monitor

Performance:
- Stable fps  75 all maxed @ 1080p
- Load times take around 10 secs

reviewText:
Lets start off by saying that I am NOT going to compare this game to JC2. In my opinion, this is an entirely different game. Of course it has elements from JC2 but I like to believe that the developers wanted to give a completely different angle. JC2 was awesome but in my opinion, JC3 is too.

The environment is absolutely incredible. It gives a real feeling of being in a Mediterranean country and I have been playing this game for around 25 hours now, and haven't even been to ~3/4th of the map.

The vehicle system is a lot of fun. The fact that you can bring cars, motorcycles, boat and even freaking planes to a garage so that you can drop them anytime you want is awesome. I have to agree that the handling of some vehicles can be troublesome, but it makes me love the variety in vehicles even more.

Some say the hate the fact that there is no sprinting, no crouching etc. Forget about that. The possibilities are endless with the amazing upgraded grappling hook you get right from the start. And lets not forget that you can use a two handed weapon from the sky with your parachute and pull yourself towards enemies to stomp their faces in. No need for crouching or sprinting.

The detail, on almost every part of the game, is extreme. For example, I was driving an F1 and a small rock hit my front axle, what made the front wheels shiver a bit. You may call this stuff a pre in a game, but I can see a lot of effort went into it in this game.

Did I mention a modding system INSIDE the game? You can complete challenges to get gears and with gears you can upgrade everything. Literally everything: Plane, Car, Boat, Weapons, Grenades and even your grappling hook. You hate repeating races, destruction etc? Not with this feature ill tell you that.

Now the last part I am going to discuss are the graphics. Which are of course, amazing. I know there have been some optimization issues, but if you meet the minimal requirements you will most likely be able to run the game fine. I use a GTX 780 combined with an FX-8320 AMD processor and 16gis of ram, and I run the game on max, max and max without any optimization issues. If you are worrier about all the loading times everyone has been complaining about, it was fixed last patch.

So if you are actually still reading this right now, whats the matter? Just ignore the freaking 64% positive reviews and buy the game to find out for yourself!

Not at all what I was promised. The car handling is even worse than in the previous Just Cause, the physics are broken, an always on aim-assist is present, enemies pop into existence right in front of you and the graphics look straight outta 2009. The bland story and characters don't exactly help either, nor does the games overall performance. My 980 struggles to hit a steady frame rate and drops from 70 to 30 very often. The drawing distance is also very limited, and the lack of an FOV slider makes it pain in the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ to both drive and aim.

So in conclusion:
I was promised a well optimised game that would address issues present in previous titles, and was instead given this bug-ridden sad excuse of a console port. Shame on you Avalanche Studios, shame on you.

reviewText:
Wow, when I saw the announcement trailer for this game I did not really think much of it.

But now, I've played it, I LOVE IT!

Just Cause 3 is a game about the island of Medici that is being overruled by a tyrant and dictator named Di Ravello who is harvesting the element Bavarium to control the island, you and the rebel alliance try to over throw Di Ravello and capture Medici.

You may be thinking, so what? Sounds exactly like Just Cause 2. in Just Cause 2 theres an island that you are trying to take back from a dictator and tyrant called President Panau, pretty much the same game. No, its not.

The level of destruction and freedom in Just Cause 2 is tiny compared to what you can do in Just Cause 3. You see a helicopter, grappling hook it to the support of a bridge and reel it in, this not only blows up the helicopter it will blow up the bridge, if you are lucky enough to do this to a railway bridge as a train goes over it, the train will fall off of the bridge and explode, honestly its great!

Intel Core i7 2600k @5.0 Ghz

Intel Core i7 2600k
8Gb DDR3
EVGA GTX 970 SSC

I have to say, my PC isn't a beast, however it is not crappy either.
