But, The game is fun. I can't say otherwise. It's really fun to play. Maybe it's just my PC which is getting old. I do want to recommend this game, it's really fun to play.
Even though I run the lowest settings, the Game looks pretty good.
It's a very enjoyable game when it works.
It's fun to mess around with the world.
I love destruction and I was very hypped by this game.

If it wasn't for the performance loss,  Id give this game a good 8/10
Buy the game if you have a powerful machine.
Buy the game if you want to play on Console.
It's really fun.

reviewText:
So far by few hours of in-game experience, Avalanche Studios has fulfilled my wishes and brought exactly what I have been waiting for long time. Hilariously fun to explore, spectacular combat with explosions, beautiful landscapes and lots more what I have not yet seen. I haven't encountered any bugs or even minor glitches yet, which has been bit surprising.

The handling of vehicles, which many other reviews have been complaining: comparing to Just Cause 2, it has been made partly better. Handling air vehicles is way more entertaining, whilst land vehicles haven't given same great feeling as on JC2. Time shows, will this change slightly, or not.

About performance, it's really easy to understand that many gamers have been suffering from bad performance, but even with my partly really old setup (see my profile) I'm able to have pretty stable 45-60fps on maximum settings, except using FXAA and models on normal (Low/Normal/High/Very High -scale). It consumes my 2GB VRAM almost fully then, and it stays there even on heavy gunfights with explosions.

Just as a example of optimization, I firstly tested with lowest possible settings and had 30-40fps, while dipping into 20'ish on gunfights. So far, NVIDIA hasn't provided yet Game Ready -drivers at the time of writing this review.

By what I have experienced in these few hours, I honestly recommend buying this game.

reviewText:
Audio - Effects : 8/10
Audio - Music : 5/10
Visuals: 8/10
Gameplay : 8/10

Overall: 7.5

What was for me probably the most anticipated title for the end of the year. I must say I wound up lowering my expectations towards the released date of the game as I had stumbled upon mixed impressions and some harsh criticism from some reviewers.

Needless to say, the game was brilliant and was an improvement over an already decent Just Cause 2, however there were a few niggles, some of which annoyed the living daylights out of me.

The game brings an impressive load-out of playable missions, objectives, side challenges. It's a vast open-world, with a hefty sequence of campaign missions that will span over the four peninsulas. The physics are brilliantly done. Tethering a chopper and an enemy soldier is somewhat amusing, or putting thrust grenades and watching him disappear into thin air.

All I can say is that being Rico for a bit is a load of fun, the wingsuit, grappling hook and parachute combinations are arguably one of the strong points of this game and provides something unique.

The good stuff:

Explosions on tap
A grappling hook, need I say more?
Destructible terrain, the usefulness of the grappling hook becomes evident when you need to pull a chaos object to the ground
Leader boards - There is no multiplayer, Avalanche has included an in-campaign challenge leader board, certain objectives are compared with those on your friends list and globally. You can also choose to invite others to compete in challenges. It's not something I've seen before, but it works.
Visually an impressive game. But not quite GTA V level, but close.
Rico is a badass. The wingsuit, grappling hook and parachute can be loads of fun, and an easy way to traverse the terrain
Large open world divided into peninsulas. Provides an array of different terrains from seaside villages to mountainous military zones.
Wide variety of military hardware at your disposable. Most of which is obtained as you progress through the campaign, in turn reducing the monotony of the missions.
Mediterranean / Italian themed - It brings something a little different to the table.
Vintage weapons, achievements and collectibles strewn throughout the map. Good luck picking it all up though. There is a lot.
Mods are available
The Bad:

I'm so sick of liberating
Vehicle handling - Cars in particular have handling that can appear sluggish at first, then suddenly whoops you're on your roof. A controller would probably fix this, but for those stuck with keyboards, car handling is not a strong point. GTA V nailed this.
Introduction skits that are unescapable. The number of times I've been pulling out bits of my hair waiting for the cut-scenes to end definitely can be counted on more than one hand.
Enemy spawns - Countless of times I've wiped the enemy towers and command posts in front of me, only to discover additional enemies have respawned in them. It's game tech from the noughties.
Stupidity - My goodness, the AI bots are incredible thick, I'm partly thankful for this as the reason I actually managed to finish the game. They get stuck behind walls occasionally. They are often dumbfounded by carcases of vehicles/choppers and seem to get stuck. Pedestrians have very little road-sense, often not stopping or aimlessly walking around infront of your vehicle, this makes car based challenges borderline annoying.
Locating enemy bases and outposts can become a tedious task later in the game as you head to larger sections of the map, guessing where they may be becomes frustrating especially when it takes you 5 minutes to fly a jet (at 350kmh, very fast) to the other side of the peninsula.

reviewText:
Update:

While this game has improved in playability, it is still a vast let down in the quality of content it has. The main island has almost nothing on it, the vehicles handled terribly and the menus still have controller icons on them in places.

Dev's have said they'd address what the community has said - well I'll believe it when I see it.

----

Day of Release Review:

I'll continually update this in the coming days but for now, day 1, the game is pretty below par. Why are we not allowed good day 1 releases? Where was the QA/testing? You don't sell me a car on release and then tell me the stero doesn't work until you patch it in a few days, or a toaster that will burn my toast for the next week because you couldn't work something out in the thermostat controls. Common Square Enix, I paid you $70 NZD for a game and I can't even get a stable day 1 play!

Cons:
- Driving, while better than JC2 still feels like you're driving a concrete block with wheels. The cars do not feel any better, sure they feel different than JC2 but not by much. This is my biggest dissapointment to be honest.
- Motorbikes, they have like a .5 second delay between when you hit the key to turn and the bike starts turning - its horrible and means you overcompensant everything and spin out... just wrong.
- Helicopters, from what I can tell feel okay but theres something wrong with how they move too ... maybe that concrete block just grew rotors?
- Jetski, try holding the reverse key and watch yourself spin in circles! For added nausia, hold the reverse and left or right key to make yoursellf projectile vomit in all the directions. This pretty much just makes you spin really fast in circles - bloody weird.
- Story, again Square Enix manages to do the whole 'throwing you into something with no backstory or character development' just take this gun, shoot those guys grapple here and drive here and meet her - sweet, heres the black market oh I mean supply drop grenade. Have fun. While Rico might know these people I certainly didn't see a familiar face from JC2 (except Sheldon). SE I thought you would learn from JC2.
- Derp eyes on Rico during one of the first few cutscences when you're having supper and talking on the fence. Just saying.
- FPS, oh how it hurts. VSync off and spin around - watch your frames go through the floor. Blow that building up? Heres you 0fps for 5 seconds reward! Yeah, the FPS is stable when you look forward... without any sudden movements (so forget keeping it stable during combat or driving and shooting!)

Pros:
- When the frames are stable, the game looks good; even on medium everything it looks really nice.
- Crash models are vastly improved over JC2.
- Wingsuit is fun (when you get the feel of it)
- Still has that JC2 feel in a new location (huge map!) and lots of cool explosions and shooting and stuff. If you liked JC2 like I did I think you'll like this - but that damn list above the pros needs fixing ASAP.

Again, I will update in a few days after some patches come out - but unless it improves on these points this review will be sticking negatory :\

reviewText:
JC3 basically takes the same formula from JC2 and turns it up several notches. The wingsuit is an absolute treat to fly around in and the new grapple mechanics give you an incredible toolkit for destruction. However, several of the notches are undoubtly placed backwards. Vehicle handling is questionable at times; you can hit a pebble and spin wildly out of control (this is even with a controller). Motorcycles are terrible compare to their counterparts in the previous game and are not worth using at all.
Medici is a vast and gorgeous place but portions of it are completely devoid of content. For example, the entire upper half of the largest island is nothing more than scattered villages and outposts.There's no awe inspiring capital city to speak of and a complete lack of more interesting and unique locales like the previous title. The game tries to pass it off as part of the backstory but it honestly feels more like a rush job.
Unfortunately the game is also riddled with constant crashes and memory leaks. Hopefully these get resolved in due time.

Recommended but with some reservation. There are some performance problems and some questionable design changes but they don't dampen the core gameplay that is Just Cause. Blowing stuff up and creating chaos in a sandbox is still some good, chaotic fun.

reviewText:
Hey do you guys like playing Just Cause 2?  Then go play Just Cause 2.  Just Cause 3 is a bait and switch.  Pure and simple.  With controls still grafted for a controller and not keyboard mouse, to the fact that the game feels completely empty despite the fact they brag that the game is even bigger than Just Cause 2.  Plus lock all of the fun graple mechanics behind some stupid upgrade system and you have Just Cause 3!  Yay!  Enjoy doing all of those mini events just to be able to reel in your grapple gun while your parachute is deployed...... which was what made starting out in Just Cause 2 fun to begin with.

So yeah the map is bigger, but having a map made out of (what feels like) 90% water doesn't mean the map is big and amazing.  It makes it a giant water wasteland.  Enjoy amazing things like a lack of interesting enemy bases, no huge sprawling cities, and no airport!

Yeah the game looks pretty, but the game itself isn't worth shelling out full price for.

I noticed that there are quite alot of bad reviews for this game, the game isn't perfect but i think it deserves a little more praise.

reviewText: It is pretty demanding, I have a pretty decent rig, and can get a constant above 60 fps at medium settings at 1080p. Going to  the high preset doesn't drop frames tremedously but, the vsync will lock you at 30 fps if you go below 60 fps. Despite this, the game still looks incredibly good even at these settings, despite some unavoidable pop-in which is slightly annoying. The gameplay is an improvement over JC2 in general, especially with the better world and addition of the wingsuit and upgrades. The driving especially motorcycles, (at least on keyboard) is pretty bad in my opinion, even worse than Just Cause 2. But the planes and helicopters are much better than the driving. Fortunately driving is avoidable if you just want to wingsuit and parachute around in classic Just Cause fashion. The gameplay is somewhat repetitive, but there is more variety than in Just Cause 2. The main story is negligible, and is really only a distraction to the main gameplay. Overall I would give this game a 8/10 so far, but I did enjoy Just Cause 2 tremendously, so there might be some bias. Thanks, for reading!

reviewText:
TL;DR: I really like this game for it's simple yet satisfying gameplay and pretty colors.

This is a very fun game. The game is based around the grappling hook, wing suit and parachute, and these mechanics alone allowed me to sink hours into it. Just flying around is very satisfying and relaxing. The gameplay apart from that is crazy, you blow stuff up in different locations, which pretty much describes the entire game and its plot. The game doesn't take itself serious (only briefly in the end for some reason), and that's what I like about it. It's just one big pile of explosions and flying around.

There's also cool challenges that you can complete around the world. What I liked about these are that they integrate with the massive open world nicely and smoothly. Speaking of the world, it's beautiful and colorful.

The game is not too challenging to complete, although it gets harder when you progress in the story (or by liberating more settlements?). Only when I tried to liberate the central commands had I any chance of dying.

In my eyes the game is perfectly enjoyable, except for a few issues: The game tries to promote the use of vehicles a lot, but there's no reason to use them as flying around is faster and more flexible. I only ever stole jets for blowing up bases more easily. The other more serious flaw with the game is the framerate. I have a decent setup (120 fps in GTA V), but for whatever reason the fps never really reached 60. At times the fps looked like it was capped at 30 too, and dropped frequently during that period. The game could do with some optimization in that aspect.

reviewText: The very first car I got into was surrounded by wreckage and on fire.  Shortly after it started to move it exploded.  That's this game in a nutshell.  While Just Cause 3 is fun if you can get it to run at a playable frame rate, if you loved Just Cause 2 and don't exceed the minimum requirements for JC3 you'll want to play that instead.  JC2 is polished, well designed, the controls are sensibly mapped out, and it runs like hot butter.  JC3 is none of these things, and should be avoided until the developers have had time to get the performance - and hopefully the interface - up to snuff.

reviewText:
Well what can i say?
To start off, i completely recognise that there are optimisation issues in this game, especially for AMD card users. However, this short review will be from MY experience alone. How i have experienced it on my set up, and everything else for ME.
Let's begin.
Story (9/10) - I haven't completed the story yet and no its not an oscar winning story, but when you buy just cause games you don't buy it for a rich story line with emotional backstories and stuff. If you want that, go buy Mass Effect. So far however, i am enjoying the missions and the story line is a huge improvement over just cause 2's. Also, im rating it highly simply because all of the missions are explosions. Which i love <3 Dont hate me ;_;

Gameplay (10/10) - This is the best game i have EVER played. No question. Everything from just cause 2 has been improved dramatically. The wingsuit mechanic is the most amazing idea ever created and whoever came up with the idea to use a wingsuit and a grappling hook, deserves a medal. It is extremely addictive and i could spend hours on end just wingsuiting around in the beautiful environments. There are Red Dead Redemption style side quests every so often, like hijacking a limo to kill the informant in it, or to deliver supplies to rebels. All of them are fun as hell and whenever i get one, i always attempt to do it.

Performance (8/10) - My PC set up will be at the end. So far i have encountered very little in the way of performance issues. For me, 99% it runs as smooth as butter, however you can sometimes experience small fps drops of about 2-5fps when huge explosions occur. Overall, i am extremely pleased with the performance of the game and definitely recommend it if you have a good enough PC, that is not AMD (well, it could work on an AMD card, but from what i've heard, less so than Nvidia cards.)

Overall (9.9/10) - No there is no logic to that rating, but it is my opinion, and it not being 100% perfect, but also being my favorite game of all time, i felt like it deserved a 9.9. (Honestly, if you want a proper review, go look at gamestop or something.) So yeah. Overall it is MY favorite game of all time and therefore i recommend it to all people. So go buy it now. Please. Its great.

8GB RAM
AMD Athlon 860K X4 (4.3GHz OC)
Windows 8.1

reviewText: The irony of fighting a group called the 'DRM' in a game afflicted with Denuvo, an extremely aggressive DRM system, is priceless. The game itself is quite poor, completely soulless with tons to do but none of it enjoyable. It seems like they couldn't decide who Rico is, the one thing the character gets across consistently is being annoying. Voice acting is questionable across the board, including the lead, which I think is part of why I find the character so unlikable, though make no mistake the writing is dreadful too. Just Cause 3 is too self-aware, it lacks all of the effortless fun of Just Cause 2. Even causing total chaos just isn't fun like it should be. It all feels contrived and pointless with few interesting moments.\n\nEnvironments are bland, graphics are disappointing with dreadful antialiasing options that keep it from looking as good as it should. I didn't have optimization issues like some people, at least, but my rig is also pretty new. Bugs and glitches abound even six months after release. Shooting is unsatisfying, the weapons don't have any punch to them. This is the point where I'd usually insert some token positive point but I can't think of one. There's nothing that Just Cause 3 does well other than maybe not being entirely broken. No single part of it is good. I put sixty hours into Just Cause 2, this has none of its charm.

reviewText:
I liked Just Cause 2 and wanted to support Just Cause 3 -- a singleplayer game (a dying breed?) with no DRM, no forced social network interaction, and a good PC port.

Unfortunately, it instead turned into my first ever Steam refund request.  The game has 3rd-party DRM, and even worse, it's hidden in the EULA linked from the Steam page instead of advertised on the Steam page itself.

The game also apparently has some forced social / leaderboard messages that cannot be disabled.

Lastly, it is not even a good PC port as far as I can tell.  Performance seems to be poor across a variety of machines, and there is not yet a performance patch that I am aware of.  It runs poorly for me even at the starting area(s) of the game after adjusting settings down.

One last note -- the game starts with a long, unskippable menu screen.  No loading even appears to happen during this (no hard drive activity), AND since this is a PC game, restarting the game multiple times is to be expected while adjusting settings.  Having a huge unskippable menu screen is very painful in this regard.

Just Cause 2 was a very pleasant experience in the above areas, and Just Cause 3 is one of my saddest disappointments I have ever purchased.  Hopefully the refund goes through.  *edit*  The refund went smoothly through in 1 day, kudos to Valve.

reviewText: A competent execution of the sandbox-of-destruction concept.  It has some significant quality-of-life improvements over Just Cause 2, reducing or eliminating the frustrations and slowdowns that interrupted the game flow of it's predacessor.  If you take the easiest approach to every scenario you will be disappointed with this game.  If you are willing to experiment and get creative, it can be a lot of fun.  There's no real consequences for failure, so there's no need to play it safe.  Some of the structured side-misisons can be a bit of a drag.  The destruction missions involve blowing up an empty enemy base that you've already destroyed once with a single weapon, and range between repetitive and frustrating.   They are neccesary though for some of the weapon and ability upgrades that make the rest of the game more enjoyable.

reviewText:
I've had no technical issues beyond one graphical glitch that was resolved on restarting, but even though I can get the game to run, there are a number of problems that unfortunately do not end at technical issues.

Number one on the list are upgrades being locked behind extremely tediuous and strict challenges that are a far cry from the rest of the games free-form chaos. The main gameplay is centered traveling from base to base with your grappling hook, parachute, and new to the series; a wingsuit. The traveling is superb, and nuanced. It's not just fun, it's something you learn to get better at as you play. After you liberate a base you unlock challenges that unlock new toys to play with, which creates a cycle of gameplay. Fly to a base, liberate it using your arsenal of weapons and gadgets, unlock challenges, complete challenges to unlock new weapons, gadgets, and upgrades.

It would be a perfect cycle if it weren't for the challenges. The infernally designed, boring, at times controller-breakingly-frustrating challenges. Some of them are just fine. Not fun, but not frustrating. Others, such as wingsuit challenges, can be so incredibly strict that IF you happen to get all 5 gears (the equivalent to a score rating, and more importantly the way you unlock upgrades), it winds up feeling more like luck than skill. Some of the challenges took me upwards of 20 times to get 5 gears, while a couple took me 2 trys. Neither instance was fufilling, neither instance felt like I got the score I did due to my personal skill. There is so little room for error, and certain challenges feel outright broken. One wingsuit challenge has you choosing what paths to fly through, each going a seperate way, which I thought was a brilliant way to solve the issue of how strict these challenges felt, until I went through one pathway perfectly, and still didn't get a high enough score to unlock all 5 gears. Was I supposed to choose a different path? Is there a specific combination of paths that is correct? Even if that is the case, that sort of trial and error gameplay is hardly compelling.

This all may seem nitpicking, I mean these little distractions are hardly why anyone plays sandbox games, but this is HOW you unlock upgrades for rico's gear and vehicles. It's LITERALLY the only way. That changes these otherwise ignorable mini-games from being distractions to being neccesary to complete if you want to get all the upgrades and unlock all the potential the games main destruction-based gameplay has to offer.

Even if the challenges had been tons of fun, this game does not add on enough or change enough to warrant buying it over Just Cause 2, not for the difference in price. Yes, the wingsuit is fun, yes the tethering system is fun. Are the new features worth $45? Absolutely not. Especially considering how Just Cause 2 has a much better system for unlocking content, I would just stick with the second one for now.

reviewText:
This game was fun, there is absolutely no doubt about that. It gives you the ability to cause pure chaos at your whim, using machine guns, sweet revolvers, a portable nuke launcher, a multiple rocket launcher, tanks, helicopters, jets, bombers, it's all there.

Take out military bases, liberate oppressed cities - all the real meat of the game. Watch dodgy voiced cutscenes as you play somewhat simple and not as fun story missions.

I just completed it at 40 hours with full 100% liberation. Fairly surprised, I'm sure Just Cause 2 was longer. Just Cause 2 also had mildly better story missions, working with three different factions which really gave it a little more worth. In JC3 it is one line of story missions, very simple (one is glitchy forcing you to restart the game), and very short mostly.  The end boss is a let down, and it feels like they jumped the shark with the missile riding ending to Just Cause 2, even including what felt like a sub par homage to it early in Just Cause 2.

Would I reccomend this game? Hard to say. I loved the mayhem, the laid back of it, it's a great game to chill with, blow â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ up, watch movies tv or youtube. Not one you need to give your total attention. I would reccomend it, it is good, but maybe not full price.

There is a season pass so I can only hope it adds some extended life to it.

Especially considering how Just Cause 2 has a much better system for unlocking content, I would just stick with the second one for now.

reviewText:
This game was fun, there is absolutely no doubt about that. It gives you the ability to cause pure chaos at your whim, using machine guns, sweet revolvers, a portable nuke launcher, a multiple rocket launcher, tanks, helicopters, jets, bombers, it's all there.

Take out military bases, liberate oppressed cities - all the real meat of the game. Watch dodgy voiced cutscenes as you play somewhat simple and not as fun story missions.

I just completed it at 40 hours with full 100% liberation. Fairly surprised, I'm sure Just Cause 2 was longer. Just Cause 2 also had mildly better story missions, working with three different factions which really gave it a little more worth. In JC3 it is one line of story missions, very simple (one is glitchy forcing you to restart the game), and very short mostly.  The end boss is a let down, and it feels like they jumped the shark with the missile riding ending to Just Cause 2, even including what felt like a sub par homage to it early in Just Cause 2.

Would I reccomend this game? Hard to say. I loved the mayhem, the laid back of it, it's a great game to chill with, blow â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ up, watch movies tv or youtube. Not one you need to give your total attention. I would reccomend it, it is good, but maybe not full price.

There is a season pass so I can only hope it adds some extended life to it.

reviewText: This game was a bit like the Star Wars prequels for me. I went to the midnight screenings of all 3 movies, hyped to the hilt with Star Wars fever, ready to love it as much as I loved the original trilogy when I first discovered that as a child back in the early 90s.\n\nComing out of the theatre my initial impression was always a positive one. But on the drive home, away from the jedi cosplayers, away from the thunderous cheering when A long time ago etc" first came onto the screen and the opening score kicked in
date: when I finally had time to myself to gather my thoughts
recommended: I started seeing flaws. At first a few minor things that annoyed me. Then a few more. Within about half an hour I was already starting to realise that it wasn't a good movie at all
hoursPlayed: that I'd just been caught up in nostalgia
voteText: no matter how much fun I had at the time. It made me a little sad the first time I realised just how badly those movies actually sucked (yes
helpfulPercent:
even the third but if you like it that's cool :D ) though by the time the third one came around I had a healthy dose of skepticism to go with my hype so it wasn't as surprising. It even happened a bit with the new one. Hindsight can sometimes ruin what was a great initial experience.

Anyway so Just Cause 3 is sort of like that.

I LOVED JC2 when I got it. Loved loved loved it. It's one of my top 10 favourite games of all time. So you can imagine my hype coming into this one. I even got a new video card just to play this (and it's run smoothly the whole time thankfully so I can't comment on the performance issue stuff).

It had fantastic gameplay combined with that B-movie/not taking itself seriously at all storyline that just made it entertaining as hell. I couldn't put it down and I still hop on from time to time to liberate a few more bases or towns.

Really all JC3 needed to do to succeed in my eye was more of the same basically. And in some ways that's exactly what I got but in others it dropped the ball pretty badly. I guess I should just list the pros and cons for ease.


PROS
It's more Just Cause. All the liberation and explosions you've come to expect.
Speaking of explosions
votesHelpful:
they look sensational. Michael Bay eat your heart out.
The wingsuit is a fantastic addition
The new grappling system is great. Being able to tether multiple stuff is really neat.
The storyline has some of that B-grade humourous feel of JC2. Some at least.
Bringing up the map to find those last few things to blow up in a base/town! That could be so annoying in JC2. Liked that this feature existed although most objects were fairly easy to find so I didn't need it too often but it was handy on those massive bases when I only needed 1 or 2 more things.
CONS
This one might be a bit spoilery so I'll hide it.  Medici itself. It just lacks the density of Panau. This is maybe a good and bad thing. Panau can sometimes be a bit ridiculous with just how many places there are to liberate etc. but it's really noticeable how sparse Medici can feel at times. Especially the final (and biggest) island. I know the storyline explains why it is this way (if you collect the Di Ravello tapes anyway) but it still sucks. I couldn't believe how little there was to do when I finally reached that island. Was a big let down.
The story. It's sort of tried to recapture what JC2 had but it just sort of fails this time. None of the characters are particularly likeable
votesTotal:
not even in a so-bad-it's-good way like Bolo Santosi and Baby Panay were. The cutscenes were all kind of bad really. I didn't mind Mario I guess.
Maybe spoilery again.  Trying to out-do the last game. It just didn't work. "Oh you rode a missile toward the end of the last game? Well you get to ride one right near the START of this one!!!" Ugh. I know partially the problem is the first one was sometimes mind blowing with some of the crazy stuff you ended up doing so it's hard to top that now but it felt like they barely tried. Oh and the very last final showdown is just pathetic. Disappointing.
Last lot of spoilers I swear!  The final two missions for each act are basically exactly the same. Seriously? Laaaame.
The parachute didn't control as nicely this time but this is super minor as the wingsuit sort of makes that gripe a non-issue.
The vehicles. They just didn't feel like they controlled as well this time around. Motorbikes were especially bad. I tried using them with mouse + keyboard and controller and neither really felt that great.
The challenges. I didn't mind the challenges themselves. It's nice having more things to do and I would sometimes do the ones in JC2 if I happened to be near one. The fact that all of your upgrades are locked behind them is the real problem. I know the collectible system in JC2 was a little clunky as well but yeah
votesFunny:
forcing you to do challenges to upgrade everything is stupid.
The Di Ravello tapes. I like collecting stuff and did all of that in this game but it sucks that a lot of the back story behind him and why Rico hates him so much etc. you can only find out if you collect these. I guess this sort of tacks on to my storyline gripe. I wasn't after some amazing story but I still feel like they could have done way more with what they had.
The online stuff can be a bit annoying sometimes. Always online DRM is never a great solution. The leaderboard stuff is a bit annoying too. I switched it to friends only which is far better but you still get bombarded with a bunch of strangers who beat your whatever score every time you log on.
That's all I can think of off the top of my head. Don't get me wrong

reviewText:
Edit: Been over a month and still cannot play it, half of the open map/landscape will not load and there seems to be no patch in sight for it. My own fault for pre-ordering, I'll soon learn; otherwise STAY AWAY from this game if you have an AMD card or any 2GB< GPU because this game will be unplayable.

Update*
I can now play it, but still loses a lot of frame rates at times where there's not even much going on, memory leaks I suspect.

Opinion still not changed on the game; although it was still somewhat fun completing it and taking over territory, causing explosions etc. I stopped playing about half way through just because it got really boring and repetative; I only really finished it just to get it done and out of the way, considering I had paid so much for it.

Pro's:

â€¢New and more variety of vehicles, finally a bomber jet!

â€¢Wingsuit is new and fun at times, although hard to get use to.

â€¢Good graphics, explosions more enhanced and guns/gunfire seem more realistic and alive too.

â€¢Finally don't have to collect stupid crates and stuff to complete a town, base or outpost etc.

Con's:

â€¢For the love of God I do not care if XxxLoverboy97xxX has just beaten my top score, go away!

â€¢Constant disconnection from said leaderboards hinder gameplay and brake immersion.

â€¢Controls are extremely clunky, and I almost wept at how poorly designed the controls were for cars, helicopter or.. heck just about everything! I thought JC2 handled like a walrus, this game slapped me across the face and said 'hey I've revamped the controls for you and now everything handles as smoothly as dfjcjuxvhxulnvxjs'.

â€¢Physics, and playing around with them, I don't know, everything just seems so.. clunky; it just doesn't work! JC2 handled as smooth as a baby's bottom when it came to the grapple and attaching things for some serious fun, this however is so painfully awkward to handle; I don't care if I've got multiple grapples and some boosters when they don't work! Too much trial and error trying to play about with the physics took away all of the fun in it.

â€¢The landscape. It is obviously a lot less diversified, and you can tell as soon as you step into the game, it feels smaller, and yet just as lifeless as the JC2 landscape was. All just grassy land, plently of islands and a snowy mountain that doesn't hold much. The big island in the top left corner was very dissapointing, at least in JC2 it had something to shoot your aircraft down. The promised 'caves' are far from caves and are more like a small arch or tunnel to go under; dissapointing map.

â€¢Story is lame, bland, stereotypical and forgettable characters *SPOILER ALERT* I had no feelings when that old woman died in the story mode, she annoyed me anyway.

â€¢Ragdoll physics are annoying and tedious as hell! I'm sick of getting knocked down by something or failing wingsuiting, only to then spend the next half hour for Rico to stand back up.

â€¢I attempted to do some of the challenges to unlock more cool stuff, to try and make the game more fun; could not do it, just couldn't. Far too many to do, and some are far too difficult to achieve the 5 cogs, so I can unlock what I need, not to mention they're so so boring. Races were sometimes impossible to do, due to the cheer clunkiness of the controls, besides the wingsuit making even the fastest cars obsolete.

â€¢Multi-player, where is it? If some modders achieved it in JC2 then surely you could, actually scratch that.. it's barely playable in single player, never mind multi; two players would make the game melt, along with your PC.

I don't know what happened here, the Just Cause series was on a winning streak, and then this thing comes along; not to mention the fact that I physically couldn't play it for two whole months because it was so broken. Maybe the higher ups took over the game and churned it out through their own ideas from a sweat shop of developers, and engulfed it into the mess that it is, who knows?

Still somewhat enjoyable, but a shell of what JC2 was; not to mention the fact that this game single-handedly has stopped me from pre-ordering games completely. If you really dig explosions and destruction with a big sandbox landscape, then go right ahead, just don't expect it to be much like Just Cause 2.

Graphics 8/10
Physics 6/10
Controls 2/10
Story 5/10

Leaderboards -1/10
Explosions 9/10

Make of that as you will

reviewText:
This review was written by someone with a gaming computer that runs on AMD products.
(If you do not care about my personal opinions, then please scroll down my review to find the Pros and Cons)

This game is by far my favourite game of 2015, and as of the publishing of this review, of all time. Just Cause 3 offered me 51 hours (as of the publishing of this review) of pure enjoyment and entertainment. I deeply enjoyed the massive open world that the game has to offer, and its beautiful landscapes -- whether they be tropical Mediterranean beaches, beautiful rock formations and archipelagos, pine forests, or snowcapped mountain ranges.

There are many people who have enjoyed this game as I have, and there are many who experience technical difficulties and feel as though they should refund their game just because of flaws that the developers are actively working on to fix. For them, I say to wait. This game is WORTH the wait. Unless your computer is actively unable to play this game, because you bought a game that your computer truly cannot run -- well, that's on you.

Pros:
â€¢A massive open world. (over 400 square miles/1,000 square kilometers)
â€¢Beautiful explosions. (A very large portion of the game is meant to be all about action, and nothing says action like big, fiery explosions)
â€¢The tether system. (This game has gone into new territory since Just Cause 2, with the addition of creating tethers between destructible objects, thus allowing more creativity for the player in how they conjure up their destruction. I can personally vouch for this, as I made a Di Ravello statue facepalm himself into rubble)
â€¢The Wingsuit. (The addition of the wingsuit has allowed Rico Rodriguez to become even more aerodynamic and powerful)
â€¢A large variety of weapons and vehicles. (From simple assault rifles, shotguns, and pistols to homing cluster missiles, handheld EMP cannons)
â€¢Easter eggs. (This is not normally a big deal to most gamers, and especially me -- but I really enjoy the easter eggs in Just Cause 2, and was really looking forward to what JC3 had to offer -- and I was not disappointed.)
â€¢Bigger and badder bases to 'liberate'. (In Just Cause 2, you never really 'liberated' places. You explored the nation of Panau and collected items in specific settlements, and then it was completed. In Just Cause 3, however, you 'liberate' towns and bases and when they are completed, the rebels are actively within it and you KNOW it is now under your influence.)
â€¢Interobject stability. (This is also something not many gamers may care about or take into consideration, but Just Cause 3 does an amazing job at keeping objects within objects stable. The landing boats are sturdy as they carry an armoured car within. They then hit the beach and let down their ramp to allow their contents to move forward. Another example is how the cargo plane can hold stuff within and still fly smoothly. Most games simply do not take this into consideration, and thus do not have it as a feature. I applaud you for this, Avalanache Studios.)

There are other pros, but these are the the most important and interesting to point out. The graphics for the game are amazing, but you can already tell that unless you're blindly cynical, or just simply blind.

Cons:
â€¢The technical difficulties. (This is by far the biggest con of the game, and it is not JUST the fault of the developers. There are many variables in dealing with the technical difficulties of JC3's launch. As I am an AMD user, I did indeed experience technical difficulties, resulting in laggy gameplay -- and later, graphic errors. However, once I had updated to the recommended beta driver, my game played smoothly (which proves my gaming computer is in fit shape for the game, it is just that it was poorly optimized at launch, but the driver basically helped it cooperate.)
â€¢The ending of the story. (There are no spoilers here, so do not worry, anxious reader. The story, in my opinion, was very nice. I enjoyed the new characters Mario, Dimah, Teo, and Annika. I also enjoyed the revenant Tom Sheldon (and in fact, he is my favourite). Di Ravello was an amazing villain; he is actually intimidating, unlike that weirdo Baby Panay. However, the ending of the game was extremely quick and did not wrap up various plot points left unanswered. HOWEVER, this game is moreso about the adventure, itself -- and thus the story's quick ending can be somewhat excused.)

This game is by no stretch of the imagination perfect. Nothing is perfect. However, I simply cannot think of any other cons that I would consider negative. With this, I conclude my review -- and hope that this helps anyone who is weary of buying the game in making a decision.

reviewText:
Just Cause 3 continues the franchise with the same mindset as the previous titles: To deliver over the top, loud, silly, big and fun action. -Explosions
-Wing suit
-Removed a lot of pointless mechanics from JC2
-Heavy weapons
-Beautiful graphics
-Leaderboards with a very nice feature
-Rebel vs Army battles

Cons
-Liberating settlements is the samething. For towns theres almost always a police station to liberate and a handfull of propaganda structures to destroy
-SAM trailers and bridges regenerate if you leave the area
-Occasional bugs (crashing bugs or game freezing)
- Driving has some of the worst physics
- Moving rico around can be a hassle and interacting with vehicles or items can be a pain
- Always online can prove to be a nuisance if your connection is spotty (constant reconnection attempts)

reviewText:
Just Cause 3 was so much better than I expected. I loved Just Cause 2 and had always gone back to playing it to goof around in and I'll definitely do it in this. I played Just Cause 2 right before playing Just Cause 3 to get a good comparison and the gameplay still feels simular but with so much more. I don't every preorder games anymore, but took the risk on this game and it was definitely worth it. But between Just Cause 2 and Just Cause 3, Rico and Tom Sheldon are the only reoccuring characters. The story and dialogue is better than Just Cause 2, but it isn't greatly story driven. Also when it comes to boss's and commanders, Just Cause 2's are tougher, though Just Cause 3 has tougher enemies. Another thing I noticed is that when it came to weapon choice, I prefered Using twin pistols in Just Cause 2 so that I could get a bunch of headshots in, but in Just Cause 3 I almost purely used a burst assault rifle.

There's a lot you can do in Just Cause 3, especially being able to have multiple grapples, being able to pull them together, having explosives that can upgrade to have jet propulsion, and much more. I abused the grapple so much for destroying things along with goofing around. It's a lot of fun grappling random vehicles and pulling them together and seeing what can happen along with occasional glitches that absolutely launch them. The wingsuit is a bit difficult to get used to, but is really awesome once you do (Watch out for trees though). When it comes to graphics, the game is absolutely gorgeous. The models and textures are absolutely amazing, and I personally think it looks as good, if not better than GTA 5 at max settings. I heard some people complain about the explosions not looking too great, but going from Just Cause 2 to Just Cause 3, it was a huge WHOA in difference. The only disappointing explosion I had the entire game was a story mission of dropping a huge" bomb into the water.

Some changes that I would prefer is to be allowed to zoom in and aim right away instead of unlocking it along with being able to do some sort of multiplayer besides having a ghost doing challenges. I also wish that it got a bit more ridiculous like Just Cause 2
date: such as the story mission where you have to take down the 3 bosses atop the Three Kings Hotel. It would also be nice for shotguns to get more ammo. I used to use the shotgun a lot in Just Cause 2
recommended: and I'd run out pretty quickly. The dual wielding shotguns are awesome
hoursPlayed: but you run out really quickly and there's no other ammo lying around anywhere.\n\nOverall
voteText: Just Cause 3 is definitely one of my favorite games of all time. Just Cause 2 was one of my all time favorites

reviewText:
Just Cause 3 is the fairly decent successor to JC2; in which most JC2 fans will enjoy. I'll be discussing what makes this game decent, as well as things that aren't so good, which will hopefully help you decide whether or not you wish to invest in this game. As a preface here's my PC specs so you can relate to my performance and such:

CPU: AMD 6350 6-core @ 4.1GHz
RAM: 8gb Corsair Vengeance @ 1600MHz
GPU: Sapphire AMD 270x 2GB TOXIC Edition @ 1190MHz Core & 1540MHz Memory
Game is installed on 1TB WD Black
OS: Windows 10 Pro

So, this game takes place on the beautiful Mediterranean island(s) of Medici, which just so happens to be Rico's homeland. A crazy, power-hungry dictator has taken over the island and you must fight to take it back (similar plot to the prequel, I know). When I say the island is beautiful, I really mean it. Even on the Medium/High settings I'm playing the game on, it's absolutely stunning, and usually get around 60FPS.

The loading times have improved since launch, still a bit slow so if you're considering installing the game on an SSD, do it!

Pros:
Pretty decent performance, hear it's not good across all PCs, however.
Amazing graphics, probably around the same sort of level of JC2.
Unlimited C4! It's explosive!
Lots of things explode, and the explosions are big, loud and pretty.
Pretty fun weapons unlocked from certain missions, including an RPG that is almost like a mini nuke.
Generally a pretty fun game, if explosions and death are your thing.
Lots of collectables (nowhere near as many as JC2, however)
Very big map
Wingsuit!
The grappling hook has been hugely improved from its predecessor.
No cash!

Cons:
You can have missing terrain if its not close to you that looks hugely ugly. This was fixed for me by installing the Beta AMD Drivers.
The car handling has been changed from JC2; it's now absolutely awful. The handling is so sensitive and God forbid you hit a rock. This is 500x worse on motorcycles too.
If VSync is on, you're stuck at 30FPS. Come on Avalanche, what is up with that?
Amount of collectables has reduced compared to JC2 (both a blessing and a curse)
Doesn't feel much of a living world, like there's towns and military bases, but nothing of importance in between.
Chaos is now pretty much a pointless currency.

Overall:
I rate this an 8.5/10; I loved JC2, and even though it isn't considered a huge step up, JC3 is still a hugely fun game to play, and there are QoL improvements such as the wingsuit that really make it shine as a sandbox game. I feel if the vehicle handling and control was fixed, it would certainly push my rating up. I highly suggest buying the game, however!

reviewText:
I don't see why the reviews are mixed. I, personally, think this game is great and was hooked instantly.

So let me start. There's a story, there's side-quests. But it's all about explosions. Goat jumps in front of your car? Explosion. Barrel of wine in the road? Explosion! Just a regular woodden box? Explosions. I'll add my specs last to the list (it's also visible on my page) but mainly the game runs at 60fps. Mainly. When driving, it's 20fps and in some explosions the fps drops to 10. I don't see it as a problem though and otherwise the game runs smoothly with no loading screens or shuttering.

But to the game. It has a story. You have to liberate cities. With explosions. Lots of explosions. It's basically Michael Bay: The Movie feat Mooch puns. No seriously, there's lots of puns. I've gotten into the game in a way and have still cities to liberate before my work here is done. But it has a story: it's just easily forgotten behind the explosions, wingsuiting, parachuiting and grappling-hooking. And the missions are pretty easy and basically always the same.

The controls are much more easy than most other games in terms of flying or driving. Shift, wasd and occasionaly the mouse. Not much of a problem here, when some games have wasd, numpad + mouse.

Only thing I'd want to complain about is the cutscenes. In a mission there's like 70% cutscenes and 30% actual mission. But yeah, it's the only con I could figure out.

I'll admit, with every setting on high" you don't expect the framerate to be so high when the game looks absolutely gorgeous. I had problems on my GTX 660 to even run CS:GO (Faulty hardware) so I'm pretty used to shuttering
date: lagging and otherwise FPS-frops so they don't bother me. But I see how it can bother people. Though

reviewText:
â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ it, I'm a Video-Game-Critic now!

Why? I tell you why: Because Just Cause 3 is a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing piece of â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥! A Metacritic-score of 74 is not acceptable for such a disaster.  Every time I try to play it I feel agonizing pain just by thinking of the lost potential.
I absolutely loved the first two games, especially the second one. It had everything, fluent gameplay, an acceptable story, a ridiculous villain, a big, diverse map, cool missions and lots of explosions. All part three has are the explosions.
Part one sure wasn't perfect, but even though the map was just as dull and plain as in part three, the gameplay was a heck of a lot better than the everlasting same â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥t we get served in Just Cause 3.

The best thing about the first game is, that you don't have to upgrade anything. Everything just works the way it is supposed to work, as soon as you unlock it. Simply by playing the game.

In Just Cause 2 they introduced the Black Market, since every game has to have upgrades for almost everything nowadays. And guess what, it was still okay, due to the fact that you were able to collect all the money and parts you needed to upgrade Rico to a decent warrior while you were playing the story.

And in Just Cause 3 they absolutely ruined their formula by locking even the tiniest upgrades behind dull and repetitive side missions, which are only there to stretch the overall playtime.
Playing Just Cause 3 doesn't make you feel the freedom of doing anything you want, like the previous parts did. It makes you feel the misery of doing the same â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ over and over again, just to unlock stuff that should just be part of your equipment from the first hour of gameplay on.

As a video-game-critic I give Just Cause 3 a 2out of 10, because it took my desires and flushed them down the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥, the same way the whole industry seems to be heading.

reviewText:
+ Vast open world, interestingly designed (big cave systems, ruins, huge structures)
+ Bright, beautiful, for games almost novel setting.
+ Destruction has never felt so good (and looked so pretty)
+ Wingsuit is amazing (once you get the hang of it, which can take a few hours - prepare to eat dirt. A lot.).
+ Tethers and explosives provide excellent new toys for creative destruction.
+ Upgrades for gear that can alter the behavior dramatically - really fun to experiment with stuff.
+ Challenges are mandatory to unlock gearmods, but fair and fun.
+ Characters are great, even if there's only a few of them.

- ish: The by far largest of the 3 islands is destined to be reached in the last third of the story. I would have liked to spend more time during the story there, but there's always free-mode.
- The driving-physics feels very clunky. Had the wingsuit not been there, this would have been a major turn-off. But instead I spent the whole time wingsuiting, which is a much more adequate way to get around for Rico anyway ;)
- Liberating of towns becomes repetitive after a while. Especially in the first half of the game, the cities are pretty similar regarding the tasks you need to complete in order to liberate a town.

Conclusion:
Worthy successor and in my oppinion best part of the series. Kudos to the devs!
Old mechanics were improved and polished, new mechanics fit right in and cater to the games flow and it is so. much. fun.

reviewText:
TL;DR Great game with fun explosions but you might have problems with an AMD card.
The Just Cause series is pretty much known for it's chaos.
Drive a motorcycle, and shoot the enemies while on said motorcycle. (JC2 and 3, possibly 1)
Get on top of a jet and rain down your RPG rounds. (JC3)
Freaking get a bubble blaster weapon! (JC2)
Over time the series got more and more upgraded.
In JC1, it's... well, JC1. It was fun at it's time.
In JC2, you get a few upgrades. Grapple Hook, better Grenade Launchers, and a better parachute.
In JC3, you get a wingsuit, an even better parachute, and better grappling hooks. plus better driving mechanics xpxpxp

But here's the thing, some people have issues running JC3, even though they have top tier hardware. From what I think it's something AMD related, haven't looked into full detail about it. So if you have an NVIDIA card like me, you SHOULD be fine assuming you have the right specs, but if you're an AMD user, you should think twice about buying this.

PROS:
1. +Better driving mechanics - JC2's driving mechanics felt very, VERY, slow. Almost to the point that parachuting is faster. Now you can parachute/wingsuit/fly/drive your way to anywhere, and still feel fast!

2. +The Wingsuit - The wingsuit is very tricky at first to master, but once mastered... it's well worth it. It's very fast, and with the right upgrades I believe that you can go almost 300 km/h.

3. +Explosions - I personally enjoy the explosions, blow a massive object up and feel satisfied for blowing it up.

4. +Grapple Tethers - This is a new feature that I enjoy. Basiclly it pulls two objects you grapple onto eachother together. It's very fun, and sometimes you can use this to destroy everything without needing a gun.

5. +The Cargo Plane - This probably SHOULD be a joke, but I'm serious. You can go inside the cargo plane, open the cargo door so that you can insert some vehicles, heck even just crash the massive plane into a massive object.

6. +Gunplay - It has been very much improved, almost to the point where I wish that the Multiplayer mod would come out soon!

7. +Easter Eggs - There are plenty of easter eggs to look for, which can be very entertaining sometimes!

There are probably a few Pros I missed, forgive me I haven't played this in 2 days so my memory is a bit off.


There are a few mehs here and there, lemme just list them.

MEH?:
1. +-Story has gotten a little bit better - I think this game has the better story out of all 3 of them. Then again, why would you buy this game for the story?

2. +-Useless" features - Let's be honest

reviewText:
Alright. I write this after the Nvidia driver was installed that was released when the game was supposed to be. Day one it was an unplayable stuttering mess of tearing and artifacts that was Batman: Arkham Knight look good. Now it actually loads up and I can give my review.
Pros:
+Massive map: This map is big. VERY big. Makes  GTA V look small.
+Dense map: This map is littered with collectibles and outposts in between town for you to explore...or destroy.
+Blow sh!t up: Need I say more? You have UNLIMITED Bavarium C4 and plenty of rockets, grenades and powerful guns at your disposal. One special weapon shoots a homing laser that calls in an AIRSTRIKE. All the cool stuff from Mercenaries 2. Of course, you can just use volatile environmental objects to blow up other objects just as well.
+Tether and Physics: You have a grapple gun that can chain together and reel in objects for just about anything. Sling an enemy onto a wall, pull a car off a cliff, launch an explosive barrel into a more explosive fuel tank, etc. Physics are a bit loose in this game, but that is needed to pull off some of the terrific chain explosions that make this game what it is. Gravity always seems to be at Moon level just when you need it.
+Graphics: This game does look pretty at max settings. Textures are usually solid and water is realistic.

reviewText:
This game is great! It's a true successor to Just Cause 2 with many improvements. Here are some highlights:

-Graphics are amazing! They are just as good for today as the graphics were in Just Cause 2 for its time. It's not quite the Witcher 3 level of graphics, but very, very good!

-Optimization: I'm getting a solid 60 FPS with absolutely no dips so far at 1200p and with maximum settings. Given, I am running a Titan X paired with a stock i7 4790K, so maybe it's not completely fair to say that. I'll try on my wife's computer with a GTX 770 for comparison soon and will update with the results from that.

UPDATE: I installed on 2 more computers: 1 with a GTX 770 and one with a 750Ti. The 770 one gets 55 average FPS with very few dips at max settings. Adjusting a few settings yields 60 FPS with no drops and the graphics are still amazing. On the 750Ti at medium settings, I average 40 FPS with a few small dips here and there, but nothing major. So my conclusion based on MY findings is that it is optimized well. I can't explain why others are having issues, but I wish them well and hope they get everything fixed soon.

-Mission Layout: This is a big improvement from Just Cause 2. The missions are spread out nicely and the pace is so much better. The raw production values within the missions are also great. They are very Michael Bay-ish, which is a good thing here!

-Chaos & Destructable environments: This is what made Just Cause 2 so great for me, and Just Cause 3 does not disappoint! They kept everything 2 had, and made the physics and destruction itself even better! Blowing up a bridge with a convoy on it is SO satisfying and a joy to watch. I also knocked over a large ball thingy with gas in it and it rolled down a hill, caught fire, hit a road, banged into a car, blew up, made the car go flying into another car, which then also blew up, and then that explosion alerted some nearby enemies at a checkpoint and they proceeded to attack some rebels passing by (I guess they assumed the rebels did it since they didn't see me do it?). And that is all just within a few hours of gameplay. I can't wait to see that else will happen!

-HUGE open world. The same size as 2 which is huge enough! Just Cause 3 has 1000 square kilometers to explore. And it's in that same beautiful tropical setting we all love (ecept the snowy parts in the mountains which are still damn beautiful!).

-Shooting, ziplining, and parachuting are all streamlined and feel so much smoother than 2 did. Gliding is new and a joy to play around with!

-Underwater is beautiful and fun to swim around in. Another big improvement.

I'd say this is a solid 8.5/10, maybe 9/10 if the story shapes up to be very good.

reviewText:
Background: I didn't play the first Just Cause. The second one I purchased from sale and played through a few times with a good amount of time spent collecting things and doing random sandbox stuff. This third one I bought on launch day and just recently reached 100% completion with around 45 hours of playtime.

The game really shines in its audiovisual department with explosions having a decent amount of low frequency sounds and flaming visuals to make them feel impactful and blowing stuff up is just as fun as it was in the previous game. The wingsuit is a nice addition to the movement techniques once you get used to it and how it is different from the familiar parachute gliding.

You now have more tools at your disposal to wreak havoc with, most of which you have to unlock doing challenge missions and a few that come with progressing in the story. To me, the most notable addition to the core gameplay is that the standard grapple hook tether wires can now be retracted between objects to make them crash together. You start with being able to shoot 2 wires, but with full upgrades you can have 6 with pulling force strong enough to lift cars. There are also rocket booster explosives that, along with tether wires, are the main tools for doing sandbox-y things.

However, there's not a lot of variety in the general gameplay at moment. The enemy AI doesn't really pose any threat so you kinda have to enjoy the core mechanics and be good at figuring out creative ways of causing destruction. The challenge missions could've used at least a few more different categories. Though technically optional, the challenges are scored based on completion time, amount of destruction, accuracy etc. depending on the type and you can get 0-5 gears from each one. The gears unlock equipment of the specific challenge type, but once you have seen all the different types they start to feel a bit of a chore to complete especially when going for 5 gears.

The random collectibles seem a bit tacked on as well, though I'm glad that compared to the 2nd game there is a reasonable amount of them and, unlike in some sandbox games, they actually unlock stuff like access to unlimited fast travel or additional weapons and vehicles. Unfortunately the guns don't have a lot of differences in feel between them and some of the vehicles (especially the motorbikes) are really wonky to control.

Like most of the other reviews have pointed out, there is a forced online leaderboard system that tracks your efforts in various different feats such as longest headshot distance, highest elevation gained with a parachute or longest distance drifted in a land vehicle. It's a cool idea on paper, but it should work more seamlessly in the background and include an option of opting-out of it or at least hiding the displayed messages that pop-up when someone manages to best you at some feat.

In conclusion, the game is pretty much what I expected from the 3rd installment; It has the same campy feel to the story missions, base liberation"
recommended: vehicles that explode like a pile of gasoline and matches from smallest of bumps and so on. Although the list of negative things I listed is long
hoursPlayed: there really are only a few major annoyances that could and most likely will be patched out in the near future. I'm hoping there'll be some worthy DLC packs to expand the list of available activities currently in the game.\n\nWould I recommend it? Yes
voteText: but with an asterisk that in its current form you might find it repetitive and thus not lasting long enough to justify full-priced purchase."

reviewText:
This is a really fun game. While not as big as the second game, I feel that there is more to do here than in Just Cause 2.
Here are the Pros and Cons of Just Cause 3:
Pros
-Being Able to walk around while Stunt Jumping
-Having a Wingsuit
-New Upgrade System (GEAR Mods)
-Being able to disable and renable upgrades to your liking
-Fun Easter Eggs
-New Tether Abilities
-More Clear objective as to how to liberate places
-New Challenges
-Fast Travel System
-New Weapons
-Collectables tactered around the world
-Explosions, just explosions
-New Turbo Jump and Nitro abilities
Cons
-Not as big as Just Cause 2
-The story is not really interesting
-No Health Bar to indicate how much helth you have left
-The Handling on vehicles can be wonky sometimes
-It can take a while until you find a settlement in one of the regions you haven't discovered
-The Wingsuit can be a bit wonky as well but not as often as vehicles
-Not too well optimized with PC (epecially if your computer is out of date)
While not the best game ever, it's certainly not to worst but I quite like it a lot which is why I already have 20 hours on in within the first 2 weeks of me purchasing it. If you like a big open world with a bit of stuff to do, go ahead and try it out when it's on sale.

reviewText:
Pros and Cons have been editedl, and thankfully now the game is playable.

Just Cause 3 is open world, action and shoot em up game set in a fiction island called Medici, which is basically Fascist Italy and Falange Spain with some Cuban elements and a leader who read Kim Jong Un's biography. The goal of them game? BOMB THE F**K OUT OF EVERYTHING. Just Cause 2 remains better, but JC3 is definitely rivalling it, and definitely better than the original.

Take this scenario: You're back from work, tired and stressed out. You're angry at the communist muslim reptile man Obama for taking your money and spending it on mexicans so they can steal your job. What do you do? Carpet Bomb civilians, because ya know, freedom.

Bored with nothing to do? Carpet Bomb civilians.

Homework you don't want to do? Carpet Bomb Civilians.

Want to enjoy a good storyline? Get a different game... After carpet bombing civilians.

Just Cause 3 is a solid 8/10, reasons below.

+Different types of assault rifles and shotguns
+You can call in bomb raids anywhere
+Name on other game except fallout where you can detonate a nuke
+You don't need to worry about money, just call in rebel drops for free fighter jets.
+Grenade Mods.
+A ton of easter eggs to find.
+One of your missions involves kissing a cow and delivering alcohol while avoiding a truck that explodes
+Italian Sportscar racing simulator 2015
-Story could be less predictable, but is a huge improvement and is longer than the last two
-Placing your triggered explosives on helicopters takes about 50 attempts
-Physics are once again a huge improvement, but still really annoying.

-----ORIGINAL REVIEW BELOW-----

As of now, I wish I opted for the PS4 version.

PROS

Its Just Cause
MASSIVE EXPLOSIONS
Cool cars
Rebel Drop is a better alternative to black market
Different types of Assault Rifles, Handguns etc.

CONS

Wingsuit is hard to get used to
Needs a JC2 control layout

Gonna wait for a patch... Right now it's unplayable and hard to enjoy. Back to Just Cause 2 I suppose.

reviewText:
Background: I didn't play the first Just Cause. The second one I purchased from sale and played through a few times with a good amount of time spent collecting things and doing random sandbox stuff. This third one I bought on launch day and just recently reached 100% completion with around 45 hours of playtime.

The game really shines in its audiovisual department with explosions having a decent amount of low frequency sounds and flaming visuals to make them feel impactful and blowing stuff up is just as fun as it was in the previous game. The wingsuit is a nice addition to the movement techniques once you get used to it and how it is different from the familiar parachute gliding.

You now have more tools at your disposal to wreak havoc with, most of which you have to unlock doing challenge missions and a few that come with progressing in the story. To me, the most notable addition to the core gameplay is that the standard grapple hook tether wires can now be retracted between objects to make them crash together. You start with being able to shoot 2 wires, but with full upgrades you can have 6 with pulling force strong enough to lift cars. There are also rocket booster explosives that, along with tether wires, are the main tools for doing sandbox-y things.

However, there's not a lot of variety in the general gameplay at moment. The enemy AI doesn't really pose any threat so you kinda have to enjoy the core mechanics and be good at figuring out creative ways of causing destruction. The challenge missions could've used at least a few more different categories. Though technically optional, the challenges are scored based on completion time, amount of destruction, accuracy etc. depending on the type and you can get 0-5 gears from each one. The gears unlock equipment of the specific challenge type, but once you have seen all the different types they start to feel a bit of a chore to complete especially when going for 5 gears.

The random collectibles seem a bit tacked on as well, though I'm glad that compared to the 2nd game there is a reasonable amount of them and, unlike in some sandbox games, they actually unlock stuff like access to unlimited fast travel or additional weapons and vehicles. Unfortunately the guns don't have a lot of differences in feel between them and some of the vehicles (especially the motorbikes) are really wonky to control.

Like most of the other reviews have pointed out, there is a forced online leaderboard system that tracks your efforts in various different feats such as longest headshot distance, highest elevation gained with a parachute or longest distance drifted in a land vehicle. It's a cool idea on paper, but it should work more seamlessly in the background and include an option of opting-out of it or at least hiding the displayed messages that pop-up when someone manages to best you at some feat.

In conclusion, the game is pretty much what I expected from the 3rd installment; It has the same campy feel to the story missions, base liberation"
recommended: vehicles that explode like a pile of gasoline and matches from smallest of bumps and so on. Although the list of negative things I listed is long
hoursPlayed: there really are only a few major annoyances that could and most likely will be patched out in the near future. I'm hoping there'll be some worthy DLC packs to expand the list of available activities currently in the game.\n\nWould I recommend it? Yes

reviewText:
I did not experience technical issues.  I did experience a somewhat bland, but somewhat hilarious, sandbox game that fills a unique niche in the sandbox universe.  To be fair, I can't even remember its prequel to compare it to, because it, too, must have had the same flaws.

This game is all about the grapple and stunts.  You can do a lot of fun, memorable stuff.  But, because of some design decisions and flaws, the gameplay doesn't feel spectacular or worthy of re-playing.

1. The controls are not polished enough.  This is something most open-world games have a problem with, but when you're gliding and grappling around it's a huge pain point.  I found myself swearing as I flew into walls or got stuck under ledges.
2. When you die, you just respawn where you left off. So you can basically liberate the whole map before doing any missions.
3. New enemies spawn behind from all sides, making battles chaotic and not strategic in any way. This negates any use of the sniper rifle.
4. Because of the lack of battle tactics, Rico is almost invincible, and so they didn't include crouching or cover because of this and the above point.
5. Upgrades (or 'mods' as they call them) are mostly optional. They help a little, but not enough to make the game easier or feel rewarding.
6. Most of the time, it was easier to glide/parachute/fast-travel rather than find a vehicle. Traveling got to be quite a shlep in the mountains.  The vehicles and attention to their detail are amazing but mostly superfluous.

These points together contributed to a loss of enjoyment in gameplay.

A typical attack on a military base involves parachuting around haphazardly and shooting missiles at targets.  This could have been much more fun if there were a stealth element, or 'level up' health/abilities before attempting, or both.

The story has a lot of interesting characters who are never fully fleshed out.  Some side-missions with them would have been fun, or at least some more back-story.  I think maybe I was supposed to remember them from a previous game?

Overall, the game is beautiful and fun, to an extent. The story isnt bad, but there's not enough of it to be fulfilling.  There is little replay value and gameplay gets repetitive quickly.  I'm left wishing I could go back into sandbox mode and have a good romp, but everything's liberated, and the battles weren't that fun to begin with.

reviewText:
So much damn fun!  If you even remotely enjoyed Just Cause 2's openness and ability to let you create wanton chaos (or you just like sandbox, open-world games), you will ADORE Just Cause 3.

The best part of the game:  the tethering system.  The tethers are the star of the show, allowing you to do ridiculous things like tying people to cars, pulling helicopters into the ground, pulling cars into helicopters, pulling enemies into each other, destroying chaos objects, destroying full bridges, pulling your character to locations or into enemies... there's just so much you can do with them that even after dozens of hours, I was still blown away by how useful and fun they were.  You actually have control of them now, too, so you can connect multiple things and pull them all together with the pull of the left trigger.

The physics are very well done and play a huge role in the game along with adding to the hilarity of whatever chaos you can create.  A lovely addition is the 'satchel charges' which you basically have an infinite supply of but can only have a maximum of 5 out at a time.  These can be modified to have a rocket effect which you can imagine can create some hilarious moments.  They're also very useful if you've run out of ammo and your tether might not be strong enough yet to take down bigger chaos object.  Attach a few charges, activate, and you're set.

Many people gripe about the challenges to unlock mods but honestly, the tethers are what I recommend maxing out (which is easy to do).  The other mods really just give you a few additional grenades or other things that, to me, weren't worth the effort.  Honestly, I think some of the mods were actually worse than the default (I preferred to NOT have homing grenades).

Driving in the game is horrible but I spent about 90% of my time traveling through the air either by helicopter (which control fine) or by tethering and parachuting/wingsuiting.

Map is HUGE but only the towns and bases are interesting.  I would wager that about 80% of the map is just filler with absolutely nothing interesting to do or see.

Despite my gripes, the game is an absolute blast.  If you enjoy physics in your games combined with a buttload of tools to create satisfying, non-stop destruction and explosions, this game was made for you.  The developers succeeded in creating an incredibly fun sandbox that lets the player use their intuition and imagination to create their own fun.

reviewText:
Here I am another player writing a long review...

After almost 70 hours in the game and doing the story line twice I've come to a conclusion that this game is great but it needs some more content in a few areas.

PROS:

1. Very fun.

2. Story line is complete and makes sence in my opinion.

3. Easy to understand gameplay.

4. Has random prop dialog (rebel and DRM dialog).

5. Has a lot of random things to collect.

6. Is a little cheaper than other new big games out there.

CONS:

1. Some glitches, here I am with a lower AMD grahpic card update because of the whole world have dorito sized chunks missing...

2. Few weapons for a game like this.

3. Little to no rewards for freeing towns unlike military bases.

4. Could use a bit of background on the characters if you haven't played the previous games.

Things that could be added:

1. More weapons!

2. Attachments to weapons would be a cool addition.

3. Different types of grappling hooks either from rebel drop or storyline.

4. More things that can be destroyed, I found a statchue that looked like something that needed to be blown up while I tried and it didn't...

5. More story line along the way for General Di Ravello (I think is how you spell it).

6. A leveling system might be a cool addition.


Over all I love this game so far and the fact that there can be so much more added in the future! These are all my opinions so feel free to tell me about yours and to let me know if I can fix any grammar mistakes :P

Thanks for reading!

reviewText: I feel the need to write a review for this since there is so much bad press about the performance. I've heard that if you have an AMD card, it will crash on you, so please research as best you can. Steam has a refund period now, so refund if you buy it and it doesn't work. I have a decent/high-end system, and I still got a few framerate drops in big explosions, but it just looks like awesome slow-mo. If you can run it, you probably won't regret buying this, especially on sale.

reviewText:
Here I am another player writing a long review...

After almost 70 hours in the game and doing the story line twice I've come to a conclusion that this game is great but it needs some more content in a few areas.

PROS:

1. Very fun.

2. Story line is complete and makes sence in my opinion.

3. Easy to understand gameplay.

4. Has random prop dialog (rebel and DRM dialog).

5. Has a lot of random things to collect.

6. Is a little cheaper than other new big games out there.

CONS:

1. Some glitches, here I am with a lower AMD grahpic card update because of the whole world have dorito sized chunks missing...

2. Few weapons for a game like this.

3. Little to no rewards for freeing towns unlike military bases.

4. Could use a bit of background on the characters if you haven't played the previous games.

Things that could be added:

1. More weapons!

2. Attachments to weapons would be a cool addition.

3. Different types of grappling hooks either from rebel drop or storyline.

4. More things that can be destroyed, I found a statchue that looked like something that needed to be blown up while I tried and it didn't...

5. More story line along the way for General Di Ravello (I think is how you spell it).

6. A leveling system might be a cool addition.


Over all I love this game so far and the fact that there can be so much more added in the future! These are all my opinions so feel free to tell me about yours and to let me know if I can fix any grammar mistakes :P

Thanks for reading!

reviewText:
One step forward, two steps back
Before I begin my review I'd like to add some context - Just Cause 2 was one of the first games I've played when I got my own pc back in 2011. It was a very enjoyable open world game that defined the current generation of sandbox games. So when Just Cause 3 was announced last year, I was genuinely hyped. Even though these days you can't get hyped about a game without worrying about how it'll perform on launch day, I didn't care, because Just Cause 2 was a very optimized game and Square Enix has a decent record of games with good optimization.

That being said, I was getting ever and ever more doubtful, how the pre-release coverage of the game showed so little as opposed to other AAA titles, how no one was talking about the map, performance or anything. Hell the biggest feature of this franchise, the map, was shown only a week eariler before release. And when it did release, I couldn't play the game because of the horrible optimization. That being said, after a few patches and buying more RAM, I finally got to play it. Now on to the review.

GRAPHICS

The graphics in this game speaks for itself. You can see farmlands, sunflower fields and scattered villages for miles. The spires of big bases have a very significant apperance of Di Ravello's oppresive regime. Beautiful sea beaches merge with coves and scattered cliffsides. At night the cities and bases light up and provide a beacon for it be discovered.

SOUND

This game is a treat for the ear as much as the eye - guns sound powerful, sports cars sound ferociously fast and explosions give that great sound of satisfaction that you may not find in any other game.

MAP & GAMEPLAY

Now on to the part which I found most controversial. The map of Just Cause 3 seems much more lackluster compared to JC2. There aren't any more landmark locations like the Mile High Club, the Radar Dish, or the Radio Tower. Instead there's just a lot of villages and bases. Sure they look unique from each other, but it's a step back from JC2. Also half of the biggest island is literally walled off and abandoned, where in a similar way in JC2 there were  a lot more villages, bases etc. Roads look like masking tapes put on the floor, the highways have no hoardings above them, there are no dividers and the biggest city - citate di ravello, is as lack luster as it can get.

The gameplay is a bit cumbersome. Auto aiming is gone, so expect a lot missed shots. The health meter is gone, though now it's the same as not getting health pack like in JC2. The minimap is gone, so you won't know where are the enemies and you won't notice the remaining chaos objects without pausing the game and looking up on the map.

Sure they changed the driving model, cars tend not to swivel out of control, but bikes on the other hand will behave realistically and just won't go straight. I wish  the Sleeping Dog's driving model was implemented here.

The biggest change this game offers is the wingsuit and in the sky fortress dlc, it turns into a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing jetpack. Though it's quite fun. It is only one step forward from the last game.

FINAL VERDICT

Just Cause 3 behaves similarly to Just Cause 2,the map has been stripped to just bases and cities. As if the developers played a lot of Far Cry 3 and added it's wingsuit and nothing much else. There is much more accesibility, and the game is still jolly good fun. I'd recommend buying now. Because once this goes on sale, it'll just be another $5 game that you'll never play , another entry in your untouched game library.
